Abkhan Hoard.description:
Gives food, minerals and item reward on death
Respawns on Abkhan Drey after 20 turns
Abkhan Hoard.flavor: Somewhere buried deep in the brain of an Abkhan had to be an instinct of pure spite. The monsters hoarded food and supplies they didn't know how to use—they just knew that we needed them. That's more than just laying a trap. That's taunting your prey.

Abkhan Hoard.name: Abkhan Hoard

Abyssal Rage.flavor: You've never known an anger like this. Humans feel rage because we find the world unfair. But the Voice could bring out something deeper. Something that fills its creations with a hatred of the universe itself. If you find yourself facing down such anger… run.
Abyssal Rage.name: Abyssal Rage

Arc Discharge.flavor: Do you know what this was? ZEPHON’s wiring ran under everything, everywhere—miles and miles of raw copper. These arcs were a fraction, of a fraction, of a fraction of ZEPHON's power lashing out at you. You could take advantage of that power if you wanted—but your enemies could too.
Arc Discharge.name: Arc Discharge

Acrin Advancement.flavor: Never count the Acrin out. They survived thousands of years in space. The blast of Fulcrum. The horrors of a ruined Earth. The Anchorite always has his eye on the long game… and dreams of a day when his people won't remember the trauma of war.
Acrin Advancement.rawXML:
<trait category="Upgrade" icon="Factions/Anchorite" rankMax="9" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<conditions>
				<unit>
					<noTrait type="Headquarters"/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<damage mulMin="0.05" mulMax="0.5"/>
				<hitpointsMax mulMin="0.05" mulMax="0.5"/>
				<unitCost mulMin="0.1" mulMax="1.0"/>
				<unitUpkeep mulMin="0.1" mulMax="1.0"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier>
			<conditions match="Any">
				<action>
					<type name="ProduceUnit"/>
				</action>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<productionCost addMin="1.2" addMax="12.0"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier visible="0">
			<conditions>
				<unit>
					<noTrait type="Headquarters"/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<strength mulMin="0.1" mulMax="1.0"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Acrin Advancement.name: Acrin Advancement

Acrin Crash Site.flavor: Every time you thought the last Acrin ship had crashed from orbit, another would light up the sky as it burned up in atmo. The Acrin looted them to reclaim pieces of their homeworld. The humans raided them to steal the technology. And ZEPHON… well, I still don't know what ZEPHON wanted. I just know we had to fight it for our share.
Acrin Crash Site.rawXML:
<trait icon="Features/AcrinCrashSite" visibleOnTile="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="EachTurn">
			<effects>
				<research add="2"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForControllingCity">
			<effects>
				<research mul="0.2"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
	<onTurnStarted>
		<feature>
			<area affect="TilePlayer" sendNotification="1">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="Every10Turns">
						<conditions ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
							<turn divisible="10"/>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<research add="10"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</feature>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
Acrin Crash Site.name: Acrin Crash Site

Aegyllan Sight.flavor: The Aegyllan Worms were so tethered to the dark and damp that their sight began to weaken. Generation after generation, the other senses—smell, sound, touch—grew enhanced, but they thought they'd abandoned all need for their eyes. Fine enough for underground travel, but when war brought them to the surface, they made for poor scouts.
Aegyllan Sight.name: Aegyllan Sight

Agile.description: Reduces  movement cost of forests and ruins
Agile.flavor: Survivors who were fast on their feet became the best at hunting prey in rough terrain.
Agile.name: Agile

Akavish Rig.flavor: This rig was a fascinating bit of tech—a muscle-modifier that could fit any human body, any Acrin body, any machine. It studied the pattern of your movement, and just nudged your muscles or motors to make you move faster. Maybe the only piece of tech we made that didn't freak me out. Sometimes I'd sneak out with one, use it to go for long runs around the base. It helped clear my mind.
Akavish Rig.name: Akavish Rig

Blessed Infestation.flavor: Runoff from our farms sometimes poisoned the very soil we tried to grow food on. Our scientists were prepared for that—but they weren't prepared for what came next: Algae took root in the diseased soil. We realized we had a vile feedback loop on our hands—the more food we produced, the more Algae we could generate too. Humans and Voice cultists would both eat well.
Blessed Infestation.name: Blessed Infestation

Amniotic Substance.flavor: Destroying the shards comes with a surprising side effect: each one leaves behind an unknown material that your scientists have never seen before. Is it some kind of… amniotic substance for ZEPHON's spawn? It seems to enhance the abilities of your cyber-augmented soldiers.
Amniotic Substance.name: Amniotic Substance

Amoetias Caress.description: Grants access to uncommon Voice items at  The Concordat
Amoetias Caress.flavor: The Concordat sent kids out into The Bleed. Bastards. Dangerous work for anyone but something about the children's small hands let them dig out crystals they needed for rare Voice artifacts. You'd buy them. The blood on the surface would stain your hands. And we all knew where the blood came from…
Amoetias Caress.name: Amoetias Caress

Amoetia's Embrace.description: Grants access to rare Voice items at  The Concordat
Amoetia's Embrace.flavor: The hooded Concordat agent drew close and whispered into my ear after we concluded a trade. “The Fulcrum's power was greater than we ever imagined… When its power washed over the planet's surface, it pulled wondrous objects through the veil of a parallel world.” I tried to pull away but he just grabbed my wrist. “You have heard their melody. And now you are ready to receive their blessing.”
Amoetia's Embrace.name: Amoetia's Embrace

Trials of the Eremite.description: Improves diplomatic standing with  Anchorite over time
Trials of the Eremite.flavor: It was the damndest thing. The Anchorite's messengers would appear out of the blue with gifts for our people. “To congratulate you for completing a trial.” they would be told. But what trials? The Practical Romantic had a guess—that the Anchorite was testing us. If we could piece together the deeds it was rewarding… we might permanently ingratiate ourselves with the mysterious hermit.
Trials of the Eremite.name: Trials of the Eremite

Annihilating.flavor: Sometimes to get a killing machine up and running, all you’d need was just a little momentum.
Annihilating.name: Annihilating

Annihilation Protocols.flavor: Sometimes to get a killing machine up and running, all you’d need was just a little momentum.
Annihilation Protocols.name: Annihilation Protocols

Anti-Air.flavor: When defending attacks from above, we could fine-tune our weapons to predict how the enemy would behave. But troops on the ground could be unpredictable and erratic. Firing on them with the wrong type of weapon could do little more than blow out their eardrums.
Anti-Air.name: Anti-Air

Anti-Ground.flavor: During one brutal siege, I dropped in on a group of soldiers training a cannon on our enemy fighters. They would take turns rolling a pair of dice between each shot. I asked why. “Checking to see what happens more often,” they said. “Snake eyes or actually landing a fucking shot.”
Anti-Ground.name: Anti-Ground

Antimatter Diffraction.flavor: Do not ever go into battle thinking you are invulnerable. Antimatter tech made mincemeat out of too many good troops who’d started to think they were gods. But there was something… pleasing about breaking through that armor, locking eyes with your enemy, and seeing terror seep across their face.
Antimatter Diffraction.name: Antimatter Diffraction

Antimatter Dilation.flavor: Children used to hold up magnifying glasses in the sunlight to burn their names into planks of wood. A Cherubim Titan could use Antimatter Dilation to be the sun and glass all at once, carving the very spirit of an empire into our enemies’ bones. If there were any bones left.
Antimatter Dilation.name: Antimatter Dilation

Antimatter Plating.flavor: Armor is a thin wall you’d put up between yourself and the outside world. But walls can be knocked down. Antimatter plating could take hits like a willow waiting out a storm. You’d hit hard, you’d hit fast, and the armor would just move with the hits, absorb the energy, and leave your enemies exposed for the follow-up attack.
Antimatter Plating.name: Antimatter Plating

Antimatter Shield.flavor: If we wanted our soldiers to have more protection we’d have slapped more armor on them. The Antimatter Shield didn’t just protect our troops, it gave them some much-needed zone control as well. Skilled groups of soldiers would team up and push enemies into everything from artillery fire to the Bleed.
Antimatter Shield.name: Antimatter Shield

Safety Disjunction.flavor: Safety measures from old-world power plants slowed us down. So we built plants in the middle of nowhere to reduce casualty risk. Funny. The top brass who decided to throw safety out the window worked real hard to make sure they never went near these plants.
Safety Disjunction.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnBuilding="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="AntimatterUpgrade">
			<conditions ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
				<tile match="Any">
					<feature type="Construct"/>
					<feature type="Desert"/>
				</tile>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<energy add="3"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Safety Disjunction.name: Safety Disjunction

Aranean Cloak.flavor: The cloaking technology didn’t make Stalkers invisible. Those spikes on their back would warp the light around them, projecting a shape that wasn’t there. What looked like a direct hit would just turn out to be empty air. We were lucky it didn’t work well at close range.
Aranean Cloak.name: Aranean Cloak

Archaegis.flavor: How do you make a shield reflect lasers hot enough to melt your skin? Or bullets that rip organs to shreds? We needed technology that could learn what kind of attack was coming its way and alter a force field to send the attack back where it came from. Planting a tiny cybernetic brain on advanced human tech was our first step in bringing that to life.
Archaegis.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Items/Archaegis" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onWeaponDefended>
		<attacker>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="ToAttacker">
						<effects>
							<weaponDamage triggerEffects="0" useAttackerWeapon="1" useDefenderUnit="1" factor="0.333"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</attacker>
	</onWeaponDefended>
</trait>
Archaegis.name: Archaegis

Archai Construct.flavor: The Krypt Archai's creations were made of material none of our techs could properly understand. I suspect this was deliberate. It tended to its own machines by using nanobots. It was willing to share its power with us—but by no means did it trust us.
Archai Construct.name: Archai Construct

Area.description: Also hits enemies adjacent to target tile at half accuracy
Area.flavor: Piece of advice: don't stand so damn close together. Hell, don’t stand in the same county. Whether it's using bombs, laser blasts, or sick flesh magic shit, titan weaponry can flatten entire regions.
Area.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnWeapon="1">
	<onWeaponAttacked>
		<defender>
			<area affect="Unit" radius="1" excludeTarget="1">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier visible="0">
						<conditions ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
							<unit>
								<enemy/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<weaponDamage useAttackerWeapon="1" factor="0.5"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</defender>
	</onWeaponAttacked>
</trait>
Area.name: Area

Argosy Targe.flavor: I happened to meet the Watchmaker that cooked up this shield once. He spat on my foot after I thanked him for making it. Fair enough—he'd made the shield to protect refugee caravans trying to cross active war zones. We “commandeered” them and made those war zones worse. He could keep his principles—I was happy keeping our people alive.
Argosy Targe.name: Argosy Targe

Armor of Faith.flavor: Most of us mustered willpower on the battlefield, but the Prophet channeled something else—faith. With it, he could do something the techs never came close to figuring out: project pure invulnerability. Was it supernatural? A power beyond the Voice? I never found out.
Armor of Faith.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Actions/ArmorOfFaith" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<effects>
				<coverDamageReduction add="0.833"/>
				<evasionDamageReduction add="0.833"/>
				<invulnerableDamageReduction add="0.833"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Armor of Faith.name: Armor of Faith

Arshem's Satchel (Gifted).flavor:
Your brother pauses as he exits the city. He hands you something—his satchel, the one he clutched in his hands in the days before the war. “We're together again,” he whispers softly. “And we have such great work ahead of us.”

You look down at the bloody satchel, and wonder just what “work” Arshem has in mind.
Arshem's Satchel (Gifted).name: Arshem's Satchel (Gifted)

Arshem's Satchel (Looted).flavor:
He hands you a box of Arshem's possessions.

You paw through them, and find a tattered satchel—the one he clutched in his hands on the last day you saw each other.

Now the tears come. You kneel before Arshem's grave and clutch the satchel to your chest. Saving these Reavers seemed such an obvious choice. You just wish you could have saved Arshem too.
Arshem's Satchel (Looted).name: Arshem's Satchel (Looted)

Artificer's Precision.flavor: The Artificer had an eye for precision. In her craft, in her programming and in warfare. When she monitored a battle, she’d use every tool at her disposal to survey and amplify all the targeting data sent out to the troops. Few other leaders were so… intimate with the killing their soldiers did.
Artificer's Precision.name: Artificer's Precision

Artillery.flavor: “It's simple fucking math Sergeant,” I said, trying to get this coward to charge through the enemy bombardment. “The cannon points up. The shot arcs up. Then it hits the ground. Between those two spots is the safest place to be for twenty square klicks.” He still didn't move. Or, he did, I guess. When his body went flying when the enemy pounded our position at sunset.
Artillery.name: Artillery

Assault Transport.description:
Allows transportation of non-large units
Disembarking units can move normally
Embarked units die when the transport is destroyed
Assault Transport.flavor: Assault Transports were best used for urgent missions where you needed boots on the ground quick. No time to even land and unload—we'd just kick open the hatch and unhook soldiers from their safety harnesses. It made for a rougher ride—but this was war, not a luxury jetliner.
Assault Transport.name: Assault Transport

Asymmetric Arbitrage.flavor: The most profitable way to deal with black markets in foreign territories was to slip their goods across the border on the back of trade convoys. Like sucker fish riding on the belly of a shark—a little free ride that benefits them, but doesn't bother the bigger beast.
Asymmetric Arbitrage.name: Asymmetric Arbitrage

Atramentous Aura.flavor: The enemy was hours away from storming HQ. We were as good as dead. But, out of the blue, our comms burst with static and an iridescent wave appeared out of nowhere. We breathed it in. Felt sharper, faster, stronger. We held the fucking line.
Atramentous Aura.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Actions/AtramentousAura" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<effects>
				<attacks mul="0.333"/>
				<invulnerableDamageReduction add="0.1"/>
				<movement mul="0.333"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier requiredUpgrade="AtramentousEchoes">
			<effects>
				<invulnerableDamageReduction add="0.1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Atramentous Aura.name: Atramentous Aura

Augmentations.description: Spend influence to improve units with augmentations.
Augmentations.name: Augmentations

Aura of Discipline.flavor: Just the presence of a Commander on the frontline could keep troops focused. We tried to capture the same effect with armored vehicles but it… never had the same impact. There was something personal about a leader’s presence, something you can’t replicate with machines.
Aura of Discipline.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Actions/AuraOfDiscipline" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<conditions>
				<unit>
					<ally/>
					<noTrait type="Large"/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<accuracy addMin="1" addMax="3"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Aura of Discipline.name: Aura of Discipline

Aura of The False Speaker.flavor: The radiation coming off of the machine is intensifying. The threads of destiny have pulled you to this moment. But what for? Is this machine an acolyte that can serve the Great Speaker… or an abomination that needs to be destroyed?
Aura of The False Speaker.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" icon="Actions/AuraOfTheFalseSpeaker" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onTurnStarted>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers endure="0">
					<modifier effectDescription="EachTurn">
						<effects>
							<hitpoints add="-4"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
Aura of The False Speaker.name: Aura of The False Speaker

Axiomatic Pendulum.flavor: Shit. Phenaris freak's blade swung right by my face. We were on the same fucking side. Screamed at it to watch out. “Pain. Pleasure.” it said, “We swing from one to another in a steady rhythm. You should too… I think you'd like it.”
Axiomatic Pendulum.rawXML:
<trait icon="Weapons/AxiomaticPendulum" visibleOnWeapon="1">
	<onWeaponAttacked>
		<attacker>
			<area affect="Unit" radius="1" excludeRadius="0">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="ToAdjacentAlliedUnits">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<ally/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<hitpoints add="2"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</attacker>
	</onWeaponAttacked>
</trait>
Axiomatic Pendulum.name: Axiomatic Pendulum

Balanced Progress.flavor: War's a gamble, right? Can't place your bets down on one strategy. Sometimes it's worth spending coin to spread out your odds, help you turn on a dime if one plan goes south.
Balanced Progress.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnPlayer="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForNonAffinityTechnologies">
 			<conditions>
				<player>
					<noBranch name="Human"/>
				</player>
 				<upgrade>
					<branch name="Human"/>
				</upgrade>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<researchCost mul="-0.333"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForNonAffinityTechnologies" visible="0">
			<conditions>
				<player>
					<noBranch name="Voice"/>
				</player>
				<upgrade>
					<branch name="Voice"/>
				</upgrade>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<researchCost mul="-0.333"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForNonAffinityTechnologies" visible="0">
			<conditions>
				<player>
					<noBranch name="Cyber"/>
				</player>
				<upgrade>
					<branch name="Cyber"/>
				</upgrade>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<researchCost mul="-0.333"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Balanced Progress.name: Balanced Progress

Biological.flavor: We had a lot in common with the monsters we faced. They bled like us, breathed like us, and died like us. Humans were always good at hurting other humans. It just took a little creativity to hurt our enemies in the same way.
Biological.name: Biological

Bionic Implant.flavor: Medic named Lucia once snuck up on me and shot one of these implants in my arm. Hurt like hell, nearly took a swing at her for it. “Toughen up you big baby,” was all she said. “Think of it as high-tech preventative care.” When I kept grumbling she smiled and smacked the shoulder she'd just stabbed. “Don't worry. I'll bill your insurance.”
Bionic Implant.name: Bionic Implant

Black Hole.flavor: Our humanity died when we began to rip apart spacetime itself. We saw reality as a machine that could be programmed. Black holes may be the darkest spots in the universe, but there’s nothing darker than a person who's decided it's time for them to play god.
Black Hole.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" icon="Actions/BlackHole" visibleOnTile="1" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onTurnStarted>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers endure="0">
					<modifier effectDescription="EachTurn">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<notCargo/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<weaponDamage weapon="BlackHole"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTurnStarted>
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<effects>
				<movementCost min="100"/>
				<movementMax mul="-0.667"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Black Hole.name: Black Hole

Blackout.flavor:
The fight is fierce, but victory takes too long. You can't access the black site before ZEPHON’s countermeasures come fully online. Your returning forces are unaware they’re carriers of a ZEPHON polymorphic virus targeted at your infrastructure.

It spreads quickly. Your engineers scramble to stop the virus from turning your power plants into fission bombs, but they fry the sub-stations in the process.

While repairs to the power network take place, your entire population sits in the dark, fingers on weapon triggers, staring into the gloom and waiting…
Blackout.name: Blackout

Bleed.flavor: The Voice's tendrils bled out from one reality and into our own, prying open a door to madness. These should not have plagued our earth. Their sickly, slimy extremities reached out in search of flesh—or metal-to ensnare. I can't even escape the sight of them in my sleep. Some nights—often on a full moon—I wake, sweating, still feeling the phantom pull of them dragging me to the earth. I assumed this was all in my head, but I've heard the whispers in the mess hall. Others dream of being crushed too.
Bleed.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" icon="Features/Bleed" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<conditions>
				<tile>
					<noCity/>
				</tile>
				<unit>
					<noTrait type="Bleedwalker"/>
					<noTrait type="Flying"/>
					<noTrait type="Hovering"/>
					<noTrait type="Titan"/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<movementCost min="100"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier visible="0">
			<conditions>
				<city>
					<noAlly/>
				</city>
				<unit>
					<noTrait type="Bleedwalker"/>
					<noTrait type="Flying"/>
					<noTrait type="Hovering"/>
					<noTrait type="Titan"/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<movementCost min="100"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier visible="0">
			<conditions>
				<city>
					<ally/>
					<player>
						<noUpgrade name="BleedCultivation"/>
					</player>
				</city>
				<unit>
					<noTrait type="Bleedwalker"/>
					<noTrait type="Flying"/>
					<noTrait type="Hovering"/>
					<noTrait type="Titan"/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<movementCost min="100"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
	<onTurnStarted>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers endure="0">
					<modifier effectDescription="EachTurn">
						<conditions>
							<tile>
								<noCity/>
							</tile>
							<unit>
								<notCargo/>
								<noTrait type="Bleedwalker"/>
								<noTrait type="Flying"/>
								<noTrait type="Hovering"/>
								<noTrait type="Titan"/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<weaponDamage weapon="Bleed"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
					<modifier effectDescription="EachTurn" visible="0">
						<conditions>
							<city>
								<noAlly/>
							</city>
							<unit>
								<notCargo/>
								<noTrait type="Bleedwalker"/>
								<noTrait type="Flying"/>
								<noTrait type="Hovering"/>
								<noTrait type="Titan"/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<weaponDamage weapon="Bleed"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
					<modifier effectDescription="EachTurn" visible="0">
						<conditions>
							<city>
								<ally/>
								<player>
									<noUpgrade name="BleedCultivation"/>
								</player>
							</city>
							<unit>
								<notCargo/>
								<noTrait type="Bleedwalker"/>
								<noTrait type="Flying"/>
								<noTrait type="Hovering"/>
								<noTrait type="Titan"/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<weaponDamage weapon="Bleed"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
Bleed.name: Bleed

Bleedwalker.description: Suffers no damage or movement penalty in Bleed
Bleedwalker.flavor: The Acrin and their pets had a special connection to the Voice—the Bleed would make way for them as they crossed through it. I think they gathered near Bleed outbreaks because on the new hellish Earth, it helped them feel closer to home.
Bleedwalker.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onTurnStarted>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers endure="0">
					<modifier effectDescription="EachTurnInBleed">
						<conditions>
							<tile ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
								<feature type="Bleed"/>
							</tile>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<hitpoints add="2"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
Bleedwalker.name: Bleedwalker

Blighted.flavor: Everything decays. Voice cultists seemed to enjoy making things rot faster. Flesh. Metal. Dirt. Didn't matter. Creatures like the Orolos spread bile over the battlefield that rotted it all. You could clean it off but… Gods the smell. Even when it burned through metal it still smelled a corpse dipped in sewage.
Blighted.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onTurnStarted>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers endure="0">
					<modifier effectDescription="EachTurn">
						<effects>
							<hitpoints add="-3"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
Blighted.name: Blighted

Blighting.flavor: Everything decays. Voice cultists seemed to enjoy making things rot faster. Flesh. Metal. Dirt. Didn't matter. Creatures like the Orolos spread bile over the battlefield that rotted it all. You could clean it off but… Gods the smell. Even when it burned through metal it still smelled a corpse dipped in sewage.
Blighting.name: Blighting

Blinded.flavor: In basic training, they blindfolded us, taught us to fight with our other senses. Great for self-esteem, not so much use against a tank. Or plane. Or gibbering Voice horror.
Blinded.name: Blinded

Breach Collector.description: Grants access to uncommon Cyber items at  The Concordat
Breach Collector.flavor: You'd better believe a bidding war broke out when some hapless hacker wandered out of a Zephon shard with half the backdoor keys for Old World tech. Concordat hosted the auction, got all the players in the room to bid… then declared it would pay the highest price, kept all the tech for itself. What was it playing at?
Breach Collector.name: Breach Collector

Broken.flavor: War is hell on the body, and devastating for the mind. Time and time again, I steeled myself against the worst nightmares a man could ever see. Others lacked that iron will. You could see it in their eyes, hear it in their breath. Death had already taken their souls, and their bodies would follow soon enough.
Broken.name: Broken

Bunker Extension.description: Grants an additional Heavy Machine Gun
Bunker Extension.flavor: Building out the bunkers we held came with risks. The greater surface area made them a larger target for heavy weapons. But there was nothing to be done. Our armies were growing, and we needed space for every soldier we could spare inside these. It was our best chance at mounting a solid defense.
Bunker Extension.name: Bunker Extension

Burning.flavor: Fire lingers. It was one of the first weapons mankind developed. It’s still one of the most important tools for our survival. Respect it, or risk being consumed by the flame.
Burning.name: Burning

Cannibalize Machines.flavor: I was jealous sometimes… these machines could fight and put themselves back together without any rest. Imagine if organics could fight like that? Every swing you took, it only made you stronger? It was only human of me to dream. At least that was something these machines could never do.
Cannibalize Machines.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="CannibalizeMachines">
			<conditions>
 				<targetUnit ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
					<trait type="Mechanical"/>
				</targetUnit>
				<weapon ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
					<trait type="Melee"/>
				</weapon>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<lifeStealFromDamage add="0.5"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Cannibalize Machines.name: Cannibalize Machines

Capturable.description: Can be captured by units of %1%
Capturable.name: Capturable

Carrion Glut.flavor: “LEAVE THEM ALONE!” The rookie was screaming at a cloud of Ioks—our Ioks—dropping on a corpse to feed. Fuck. It was our medic. I'd seen those two sneaking off to lock lips when they thought I wasn't looking. The Ioks didn't care. One swiped at the kid when they tried to get close. I grabbed them… made her look away as they turned their lover into human jerky.
Carrion Glut.name: Carrion Glut

Causal Well.flavor: A spiraling energy exchange whirled around the Acrin titan. The fingers on its flesh pulsed in and out, sucking the spirit out of anything—machine, human, or Voice cultist—that drew close. Unless it liked you of course. Then those fingers drifted over your skin, giving you a taste of the life it stole.
Causal Well.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onTurnStarted>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers endure="0">
					<modifier effectDescription="ToAlliedBiologicalUnitsEachTurn">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<ally/>
								<trait type="Biological"/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<hitpoints add="4"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
					<modifier effectDescription="ToEnemyUnitsEachTurn">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<enemy/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<hitpoints add="-4"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
Causal Well.name: Causal Well

Cherubic Hallowing.flavor: The Cherubim had the power to expand their shielding to other units in the area. The sensation was… comforting. Oddly pleasant. A great weapon of war wrapping you up in its embrace, offering protection, and sanctuary… while its guns pounded the enemy into mulch.
Cherubic Hallowing.name: Cherubic Hallowing

Reaver Immigration.description: Improves diplomatic standing with  Chieftess over time
Reaver Immigration.flavor: No deal with the Chieftess came with guarantees—except for one. She made it known that anyone who allowed Reavers to mingle with their people would drop off her shit list. “It's just good manners,” she'd say if you pressed her on it. Was it a streak of kindness for her people? Or some kind of plan to infiltrate us and take over?
Reaver Immigration.name: Reaver Immigration

Enmeshed Savant.flavor: If we wanted to enhance our Chip production, we had to make a hard decision. We screened the populace for the best minds possible—minds we could permanently integrate in the hardware of our Fabricators. I wanted to lie to them—let them live in ignorance until the last possible moment. But you can't go looking for the sharpest minds in your society, and expect them to be selectively dull.
Enmeshed Savant.name: Enmeshed Savant

Cicadas.flavor: Look, I don't make the rules. Bugs were rich in protein and easy to cook into larger meals. Some of our people had lived in pre-war countries where cicadas were regularly on the menu. Catching them kept our people's bellies fed, and anyone who complained—well, they had two choices: starve, or swallow their pride.
Cicadas.name: Cicadas

City.flavor: Urban warfare is brutal. Every piece of cover that protects your troops feels like it gives double the shielding to your enemy. I preferred defending cities under siege than street-to-street fighting. In a siege, you felt solidarity with civilians and other soldiers. In the streets, you could only trust your squad. Anyone else might sell you out.
City.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Features/City" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<conditions>
				<tile>
					<noFeatureCategory name="Bleed"/>
				</tile>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<movementCost max="0.75"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForNonLargeGroundUnitsAgainstRangedWeapons">
			<conditions>
				<unit>
					<noTrait type="Flying"/>
					<noTrait type="Large"/>
				</unit>
				<weapon ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
					<noTrait type="Melee"/>
					<noTrait type="TitanMelee"/>
				</weapon>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<coverDamageReduction add="0.333"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForAlliedUnits">
			<conditions>
				<unit>
					<ally/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<cityDamageReduction add="0.333"/>
				<healingRate mul="1.0"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
City.name: City

Urban Sprawl.flavor: I didn't like how quickly we expanded. Smaller cities were easier to defend, and even easier to evacuate when chips were down. But the architects told me that growth was inevitable. “Density breeds efficiency,” they said. “We can't waste any resources at a time like this.”
Urban Sprawl.name: Urban Sprawl

Perimeter Extension.flavor: Stretch your HQ out too far and it might collapse under its own weight. Good leaders were careful, built up a strong foundation to stand on, then sped up expansion that turned small bases into mini metropolises.
Perimeter Extension.name: Perimeter Extension

Cliff.flavor: Mother nature made her own walls that shaped the battlefield. Tall cliffs couldn't be broken, and savvy leaders used them to mount a strong defense. But our enemies could safely snipe at us from the high rocks, or box troops into canyons where there was no escape. Know the terrain, or it will be used against you.
Cliff.name: Cliff

Combat Routine.flavor: The first machines we encountered weren’t always fully ready for combat—but they would be once the shooting started. It was eerie how they’d become better shots once they took a hit. Some kind of triangulation subroutine or something.
Combat Routine.name: Combat Routine

Combat Shield.flavor: The head of our medical corps was reluctant to distribute these shields to those under their command. I cornered them one day to ask why. “When we carry these into battle… we look more like riot cops than healers. Will our people trust us?” I couldn't respond. I couldn't tell them we might have to task medics with keeping order.
Combat Shield.name: Combat Shield

Premium Access.flavor: To access the Concordat’s best caches–the stuff they had locked away in hidden cells and bunkers—you had to prove yourself. Prove your loyalty. Send a few “volunteer” scientists with nothing to live for, to show you’d sacrifice your best to whatever the Concordat was. And never, NEVER, ask what happens to them.
Premium Access.name: Premium Access

Concussed.flavor: When your head pounded and all you could hear was a high-pitched whine, the best you can do was fire blindly and hope you’d hit something.
Concussed.name: Concussed

Concussive.flavor: Not every shot needed to kill. Sometimes throwing off their aim was all you needed to survive.
Concussive.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnWeapon="1">
	<onWeaponAttacked>
		<defender>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="ToBiologicalEnemy">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<trait type="Biological"/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<addTrait type="Concussed" duration="1"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</defender>
	</onWeaponAttacked>
</trait>
Concussive.name: Concussive

Cone.description: Also hits enemies left and right of target tile at half accuracy
Cone.flavor: In the war's early days that idea of sky-high monsters breathing fire over miles and miles still seemed the stuff of bad movies we watched in the bunker. But then we'd encounter the Abkhan—a creature that could breathe out a blizzard that swallowed whole armies. I began dreaming of other terrors. Beasts that could breathe acid, radiation or lightning. It made me miss my old nightmares.
Cone.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnWeapon="1">
	<onWeaponAttacked>
		<defender>
			<cone affect="Unit" excludeTarget="1">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier visible="0">
						<conditions ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
							<unit>
								<enemy/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<weaponDamage useAttackerWeapon="1" factor="0.5"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</cone>
		</defender>
	</onWeaponAttacked>
</trait>
Cone.name: Cone

Industrial Density.flavor: Time was already running out the second we brought our first cities online. The Engineers informed us they could speed up construction—but it would cost more power. “Make sure you can run that kind of voltage,” one engineer warned us. “If the electricity cuts out while a crane's hauling material—it might be you it comes crashing down on.”
Industrial Density.name: Industrial Density

Contagious.flavor: Strike a Fallen Orolos with blade or bare hand and some of the cancer it was borne from stuck on you. If you were lucky, it would die out fast, only taking a chunk of flesh as it went. If you weren't, it would bore through skin, fat, and muscle. Probably wouldn't kill you instantly… But it might just be the thing that did you in.
Contagious.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onUnitDefended>
		<attacker>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="ToMeleeAttackers">
						<conditions>
							<unit ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
								<firingMeleeWeapons/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<addTrait type="Blighted" duration="1"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</attacker>
	</onUnitDefended>
</trait>
Contagious.name: Contagious

Corpse Cities.description: Grants access to uncommon Human items at  The Concordat
Corpse Cities.flavor: Concordat operatives would whisper about scavenging bodies, digging through the flesh to find the most valuable pieces. Told them it was disgusting. Got weirded out when they said I do it too. “You pull apart the metal flesh of the land to find rewards… we do too.” They were talking about looting cities. Did they… think cities were alive once?
Corpse Cities.name: Corpse Cities

Corroded.flavor: A festering wound can make for a painful death—but machines don't become wounded. You could still poison their chassis, strip back the armor, and expose the vulnerable systems underneath. You just needed the right weapon for the job.
Corroded.name: Corroded

Corrosive.flavor: A festering wound can make for a painful death—but machines don't become wounded. You could still poison their chassis, strip back the armor, and expose the vulnerable systems underneath. You just needed the right weapon for the job.
Corrosive.name: Corrosive

Cost of Conviction.flavor: Con artists and cult leaders shared a common technique—if you can convince your audience they need you to survive, you'll have power over them. But the Prophet knew he had to tread carefully—one wrong step, one chance for his people to slip back to reality—and they'd run from him like rats fleeing a sinking ship.
Cost of Conviction.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnCity="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<effects>
				<populationInfluenceUpkeep add="0.5"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier effectDescription="WhileAbove2Loyalty" requiredUpgrade="CostOfConvictionUpgrade">
			<conditions>
				<city>
					<loyalty greater="2"/>
				</city>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<populationInfluenceUpkeep add="-0.5"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier effectDescription="WhileAbove8Loyalty" requiredUpgrade="CostOfConvictionUpgrade2">
			<conditions>
				<city>
					<loyalty greater="8"/>
				</city>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<populationInfluenceUpkeep add="-0.5"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Cost of Conviction.name: Cost of Conviction

Cr'la's Gambit.flavor: The Disciples of Cr'la never seemed to respect the same reality as the rest of us. Every time they invoked Cr'la's will, one of their number would fall. No creature with a sense of self-preservation would fight like that. They fought for a higher cause—and that cause demanded a life for a life.
Cr'la's Gambit.name: Cr'la's Gambit

Crippled.flavor: When you couldn’t run, you risked becoming your own worst enemy. All of your muscles would scream at you to flee but you had to resist that temptation. You fought like it was your last day on the planet. Doing so let some of us make it to the next one.
Crippled.name: Crippled

Crippling.flavor: It was much easier to secure a kill if your target couldn’t run away from you.
Crippling.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnWeapon="1">
	<onWeaponAttacked>
		<defender>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="ToNonLargeEnemy">
						<conditions ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
							<unit>
								<noTrait type="Large"/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<addTrait type="Crippled" duration="1"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</defender>
	</onWeaponAttacked>
</trait>
Crippling.name: Crippling

Cross.description: Also hits behind, left and right of target tile
Cross.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnWeapon="1" visible="0">
	<onWeaponAttacked>
		<defender>
			<cross affect="Unit" excludeTarget="1">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier visible="0">
						<effects>
							<weaponDamage useAttackerWeapon="1"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</cross>
		</defender>
	</onWeaponAttacked>
</trait>
Cross.name: Cross

Cruel.flavor:
The Acrin deserve no quarter. They descended upon your world as destroyers. Their fanaticism is what doomed both your species.

Nobody speaks. Nobody has to. You put a bullet into the makeshift speaker. Its mechanical whine slurs to a stop. Your soldiers start shooting, their inner demons appeased, however briefly, by powder-light and rifle-fire. Afterwards you loot the compound before razing it.

News of your deed spreads throughout the factions. The Anchorite is furious, but when did you care what hypocrites think? The others all seem pleased or intimidated—something that you can leverage into future favors.
Cruel.name: Cruel

Crystal Basin.flavor: Mineral-rich mining hubs didn't just make for good resource hubs, they also provided plenty of cover. We learned to build fortresses in regions like these and use them to harden our borders. Sure, they became high-value targets when our enemies wanted to hit our supply lines—but to lay the best traps, you need the best bait.
Crystal Basin.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Features/CrystalBasin" visibleOnTile="1" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForStationedUnit">
			<effects>
				<invulnerableDamageReduction add="0.167"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Crystal Basin.name: Crystal Basin

Cult Expansion.flavor: The Prophet's Cultist had it down to a science. When their leader laid claim to a city, they flooded it with zealots and proselytizers. It didn't matter how many converted to the cause. Plenty of non-believers kept their heads down, worried that their neighbor would turn them in for any half-uttered sacrilege.
Cult Expansion.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnCity="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<effects>
				<cityLoyaltyUpkeep mul="-0.25"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier requiredUpgrade="CultExpansionUpgrade">
			<effects>
				<cityLoyaltyUpkeep mul="-0.25"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier requiredUpgrade="CultExpansionUpgrade2">
			<effects>
				<cityLoyaltyUpkeep mul="-0.25"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Cult Expansion.name: Cult Expansion

Cursecharm of Cr'la.flavor: Turn one of these over, and you'll find a curse written in ancient Acrin. “Old wounds can always be reopened.” The Voice couldn't always hurt you… but at the worst moments, it knew how to make you remember all the pain you'd ever felt.
Cursecharm of Cr'la.name: Cursecharm of Cr'la

Babellian Beacon.flavor: Sky fortresses erected on tall mountains could be seen for miles. By the time we were building them, the techs were cooking up ways to program machines through light itself. Pairing them together made sense. If every time a machine looked up it saw the fortress—it could sync with the rest of the network and feel like a part of a greater whole.
Babellian Beacon.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnBuilding="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="OnHeight3">
			<conditions ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
				<tile>
					<height equal="3"/>
				</tile>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<loyalty add="1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier effectDescription="OnHeight4">
			<conditions ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
				<tile>
					<height equal="4"/>
				</tile>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<loyalty add="2"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Babellian Beacon.name: Babellian Beacon

Interpolated Production.flavor: Tasked with increasing troop output, the Techs knew the only solution was to turn to more and more automated processing. They linked the Printers' operating units into a single network. The more of them you had in a city, the faster it optimized production… and the more control you handed over to a new artificial life form.
Interpolated Production.name: Interpolated Production

Insight Integration.flavor: A technician stationed at the Network Splitters cooked up plans for reviving a retro phone network between stations—the kind with switchboards that you could hack by playing the right tone. In the old days, it'd be a security nightmare. Now? “No one's creeping around telecom buildings to jack into phone lines,” they said. “Let's milk some extra processing with their help.”
Insight Integration.name: Insight Integration

Subatomic Displacement.flavor: The machines saw something in our designs that we didn't. They tried to leave us hints—but when we were blind to them, they took matters into their own hands. We arrived one day to find our facilities upgraded, now producing antimatter along with our heavy armor. That was the point we began to lose control.
Subatomic Displacement.name: Subatomic Displacement

Damaged.flavor: I landed a lucky shot on the eye of a Stalker that had pinned me down. It kept firing as I moved to finish it off, but every shot went wide. Was it… screaming, as I approached? I'd taken away the only purpose it had: to kill with precision. It died spraying laser fire everywhere, hitting nothing. Its worst nightmare.
Damaged.name: Damaged

Dark Caress.flavor: Could you imagine the touch of those foul fingers? Picture a giant hand reaching down to brush your shoulder like a long-lost love? It dreams of that. It remembers such a sensation. And that desire is what you will feel when it reaches out for you in the heat of battle.
Dark Caress.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Actions/DarkCaress" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onTurnStarted>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers endure="0">
					<modifier effectDescription="EachTurn">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<ally/>
								<trait type="Biological"/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<hitpoints add="1"/>
							<morale add="1"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
Dark Caress.name: Dark Caress

Dark Omen.flavor: The Tribunal had a sixth sense for when it was in danger—and the Voice was happy to reveal how close its enemies were. That kind of recon capability could have saved lives if the witches had shared it with humanity. But they were selfish. They only wanted to protect the Voice.
Dark Omen.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" icon="Actions/DarkOmen" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<opponentModifiers>
 		<modifier requiredUpgrade="DarkOmenUpgrade" effectDescription="AgainstThisUnit">
			<conditions>
				<unit>
					<enemy/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<attacks mul="0.167"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</opponentModifiers>
	<onTraitAdded>
		<tile>
			<area affect="Tile">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier>
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<enemy/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<reveal/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</tile>
	</onTraitAdded>
	<onTurnStarted>
		<tile>
			<area affect="Tile">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier visible="0">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<enemy/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<reveal/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</tile>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
Dark Omen.name: Dark Omen

Data Hack.flavor: The Emulated Mind knew the back roads and less-used byways of every networking system. She loathed using such paths, but found there was some purpose to them. She’d reach out her mind, walk through the back door, and have a look at what our enemies were researching. She could accept that function.
Data Hack.rawXML:
<trait icon="Actions/DataHack" visibleOnCity="1" visibleSourcePlayer="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<effects>
				<researchFromCity mul="1.0"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier requiredUpgrade="DataHackUpgrade">
			<effects>
				<resourcesFromCity mul="0.2"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Data Hack.name: Data Hack

Deathshriek.flavor: Priests of Phenaris whispered about their master's most prime edict: that before they die they scream his true name in the tongue it was meant to be spoken in. Made me think of a grandmother I met in the slums, who warned against speaking the true name of the god she worshiped. A warning shared by her ancestors from thousands of years in the past.
Deathshriek.name: Deathshriek

Decoy Flares.flavor: Funny thing, flares. Pilots who deploy them don't see them. Missiles they're scrambling don't know what they are. The people who lay eyes on them are usually troops on the ground—the ones who have a second to look up and see them move like slow lightning through the sky.
Decoy Flares.name: Decoy Flares

Defense Matrix.flavor: Some machines could be programmed to be ever vigilant and always respond to enemy movement. Running those intense calculations came with a trade-off in power, but we slept slightly easier with that extra line of defense.
Defense Matrix.name: Defense Matrix

Deflector Shield.flavor: The escalation was unending. Every new weapon the techs handed us would be matched by something equally powerful and frightening out on the battlefield. We realized if we wanted to win, we would need to turn our enemy’s weapons back against them.
Deflector Shield.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onWeaponDefended>
		<attacker>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="ToAttacker">
						<effects>
							<weaponDamage triggerEffects="0" useAttackerWeapon="1" useDefenderUnit="1" factor="0.167"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</attacker>
	</onWeaponDefended>
</trait>
Deflector Shield.name: Deflector Shield

Deforming.flavor: The Voice has the power to animate rapidly decaying flesh. It makes an abomination out of the cycle of life, death, and rebirth—a cycle that was never meant to run so fast and with such chaos.
Deforming.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onOpponentKilled>
		<defender>
			<area affect="Tile">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="WhenKillingNonDeformingBiologicalUnit">
						<conditions ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
							<unit>
								<trait type="Biological"/>
								<noTrait type="Deforming"/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<addUnit type="Deformity" avoidBleed="0" avoidCity="0" consumedAction="1" consumedMovement="1"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</defender>
	</onOpponentKilled>
</trait>
Deforming.name: Deforming

Decaying.flavor: Deformities were not meant to linger in this world. They lived just long enough to drag someone back to the grave with them. Every moment they were not in the belly of the Shoch'itris, flesh would slough off their body and drip to the ground. Like melting cheese.
Decaying.name: Decaying

Deported Reavers.flavor: Removing the Reavers is harder than it looks—they riot as they leave, burning down parts of the town. When the smoke clears, many citizens have gone with them—both those who’d advocated for them and others, disgusted by your reactionary behavior.
Deported Reavers.name: Deported Reavers

Ichor of Uzhodai.flavor: An Elect of Uzhodai gave a sermon outside a Sealed Hermitage facility. Tendrils of Bleed wound their way up the building and the cries of the immured cultists turned into wails of ecstasy. The Bleed's power bound them to their supposed God—and more and more echoes poured out of the screaming souls inside.
Ichor of Uzhodai.name: Ichor of Uzhodai

Dimensional Reverberations.flavor: Plangent Orolos were so connected to the Voice they could extract Dimensional Echoes from anything they killed. Why? How? Too late in the war… too much in my head to even try and explain it. Just warned our troops if this thing killed them, their very souls could be yanked out and fed to the war machine.
Dimensional Reverberations.name: Dimensional Reverberations

Direct Control.flavor: We ambushed a patrol of ZEPHON's machines, hoping to scrap them for parts. One of them suddenly twitched violently and its circuits glowed a terrifying color I can't describe—before slaughtering a squad of Militia in a single stroke. I made eye contact with the thing and it felt like ZEPHON itself was looking back at me.
Direct Control.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Actions/DirectControl" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<effects>
				<damage mul="0.5"/>
				<invulnerableDamageReduction add="0.333"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
	<onTurnStarted>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers endure="0">
					<modifier effectDescription="EachTurn">
						<effects>
							<hitpoints add="2"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
Direct Control.name: Direct Control

Disputation.flavor: Troops of the religious sort told tales about spiritual leaders lashing kids with the whip when they showed even a shred of insolence. Provosts worked the same way. Strike them and they'd take it PERSONALLY. Their limbs would lash out, like a cracking whip, just to hurt the thing closest to it and gain any sense of control.
Disputation.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onWeaponDefended>
		<defender>
			<area affect="Unit" radius="1">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="ToAdjacentEnemyUnits">
						<conditions>
							<unit ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
								<enemy/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<weaponDamage triggerEffects="0" useAttackerWeapon="1" factor="0.167"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</defender>
	</onWeaponDefended>
</trait>
Disputation.name: Disputation

Distorted Lens.flavor: Some worshippers of the Voice carried polished monocles that distorted the light around them. Their victims could SEE the Voice's whispers—not just hear them——and what they saw would scrape at the edges of their brains. You'd feel this pain in your soul you couldn't unsee, and you'd wonder what was even the point of fighting back.
Distorted Lens.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Items/DistortedLens" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onUnitAttacked>
		<defender>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="ToAttackedEnemy">
						<effects>
							<morale add="-2"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</defender>
	</onUnitAttacked>
</trait>
Distorted Lens.name: Distorted Lens

Dozer Blade.description: Reduces  movement cost of forests and ruins
Dozer Blade.flavor: We stripped dozer blades off of old construction vehicles so that our heavy armor could clear out terrain. If we hadn't strapped them on, we'd have lost so many troops to thick forests and dense, tangled ruins. I think some operators preferred clearing out terrain to open combat.
Dozer Blade.name: Dozer Blade

Dragoon Armor.flavor: An Acrin shaman explained to me that forging Dragoon Armor was an ancient tradition that predated the Voice coming to their world. It was one of their last ties to a peaceful era. “The tools we enter the world with are the tools we will need when it comes to an end,” she said. I could only think about how from their earliest days, the Acrin must have been thinking about the apocalypse.
Dragoon Armor.name: Dragoon Armor

Dream Prison.flavor: 30 Militants. Two Missile Teams. A Praetorian. That's how many I killed while the Dreameater took over my mind. I told Command I was brainwashed and had no memory of it but that was a lie. It fed me a vision of hunting deer in the woods. Downing them. Stalking them. Skinning them. Each one screaming for help as I plunged a knife in its ribs…
Dream Prison.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" icon="Actions/DreamPrison" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onTraitAdded>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier>
						<effects>
							<changePlayer changeOwner="0"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTraitAdded>
	<onTraitRemoved>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="DreamPrisonRestore">
						<effects>
							<changePlayerToOwner/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTraitRemoved>
	<opponentModifiers>
		<modifier visible="0">
			<effects>
				<attackScore mul="-0.5"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</opponentModifiers>
</trait>
Dream Prison.name: Dream Prison

Sandstorm.flavor: Armor could block the sand. Scanners could penetrate the darkness. But nothing could protect your mind from the wrath of it all. Lightning, sand and wind all blurred together and the Earth ROARED in vengeance. It knew about the violence we'd brought to its surface and this, this storm, was its way of fighting back.
Sandstorm.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" icon="Features/DustStorm" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<conditions>
				<unit>
					<notCargo/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<movementCost add="1"/>
				<sight max="1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier effectDescription="AgainstRangedWeapons">
			<conditions>
				<unit>
					<notCargo/>
				</unit>
				<weapon ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
					<noTrait type="Melee"/>
					<noTrait type="TitanMelee"/>
				</weapon>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<coverDamageReduction add="0.333"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
	<onTurnStarted>
		<tile>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers endure="0">
					<modifier effectDescription="EachTurn">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<notCargo/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<weaponDamage weapon="DustStorm"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</tile>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
Sandstorm.name: Sandstorm

Dynameis Plate.flavor: When we were building machines that could think for themselves, this chunk of armor didn't seem all that impressive. But the engineers who cooked it up had made a quiet miracle for us: the metal would turn to liquid, enhance the armor it was fused with, and made it even stronger.
Dynameis Plate.name: Dynameis Plate

EMP.flavor: Electromagnetic pulse-based weaponry was an oddly old trick for a new age. In the wars of the old world, military leaders were just worried about the damage to civilian electronic infrastructure. But what did we care now? We just needed to fry machinery as fast as we could.
EMP.rawXML:
<trait icon="Weapons/EMP" visibleOnWeapon="1">
	<onWeaponAttacked>
		<defender>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="ToMechanicalNonTitanEnemy">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<trait type="Mechanical"/>
								<noTrait type="Titan"/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<addTrait type="Stunned" duration="1"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</defender>
	</onWeaponAttacked>
</trait>
EMP.name: EMP

Eventful Horizons.flavor: The Emulated Mind's core database contained exabytes of singularity research from Old World universities. When ZEPHON woke her up it literally birthed her with knowledge of black holes no one else could access… maybe the impossible calculations that could create an event horizon were what had first driven her so mad.
Eventful Horizons.name: Eventful Horizons

Biomass Generator.flavor: The most extreme climates on planet Earth were packed with extremophile life forms that survived in impossible conditions. Our Techs found that some life deep in the most toxic swamps and buried under the arctic ice, could be used to fuel exponential energy production. Like pulling up fossil fuels from the earth—except the creatures hadn't yet been fossilized.
Biomass Generator.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnBuilding="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="EnergyUpgrade">
 			<conditions ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
				<tile match="Any">
					<feature type="Arctic"/>
					<feature type="Swamp"/>
				</tile>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<energy add="1.5"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Biomass Generator.name: Biomass Generator

Engineer Life.flavor: “Life is cheap. I can make life with the snap of my fingers. What is difficult, is making life that fulfills a purpose. Humanity struggled with its purpose for ages. It's time I decided what is best for them.” —Artificer's Log: Date Unknown
Engineer Life.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnCity="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<conditions>
				<building>
					<type name="Headquarters"/>
				</building>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<growth add="2"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier requiredUpgrade="EngineerLifeUpgrade">
			<conditions>
				<building>
					<type name="Headquarters"/>
				</building>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<growth add="1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier requiredUpgrade="EngineerLifeUpgrade2">
			<conditions>
				<building>
					<type name="Headquarters"/>
				</building>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<growth add="1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Engineer Life.name: Engineer Life

Enhanced Probability Augment.flavor: Gunslingers of old needed intuition to land a deadeye shot. The Operative looked to them for inspiration for this particular augment. Intuition could be… simulated. Redesigned with equations. She had such an eye for taking what made us human and recreating it with just numbers.
Enhanced Probability Augment.name: Enhanced Probability Augment

Enslaved Reavers.flavor: Your reputation for cruelty soon extends across the land. What you call ‘indentured labor’ others rightly call slavery—and, wherever they are, Reavers are justifiably furious with you and redouble their attacks. Even your citizens wonder at your choice.
Enslaved Reavers.name: Enslaved Reavers

Entomb.flavor: The Archai had the power to exploit every one of your vulnerabilities all at once. If it locked you down… you couldn’t move. You could barely breathe. If there wasn’t someone who could pull you out of there, that was it, you were dead. All you could do is watch, eyes locked open, as your enemies lined up the killing blow.
Entomb.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" icon="Actions/Entomb" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<effects>
				<actionPointsMax max="0"/>
				<movementMax max="0"/>
				<healingReceived mul="-0.75"/>
				<damageTaken mul="0.333"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Entomb.name: Entomb

Essence Syphon.flavor: The Leviathan’s skin would harden with every life it crushed beneath its feet. The cultists thought Vorodai itself was rewarding the beast with each kill, like a treat you'd give to a favored pet. Little did they know…
Essence Syphon.name: Essence Syphon

Essence Syphoned.flavor: The Leviathan’s skin would harden with every life it crushed beneath its feet. The cultists thought Vorodai itself was rewarding the beast with each kill, like a treat you'd give to a favored pet. Little did they know…
Essence Syphoned.name: Essence Syphoned

Evasion Processor.flavor: The Erelim could let her machine side take over—just a little—to walk in between the hail of bullets. She lured enemies close, thinking they could land a blow at close-quarters. But close-quarters is where the Erelim do their best work.
Evasion Processor.name: Evasion Processor

Evasive Maneuvers.flavor: Rookie pilots were sent up with a manual of routine maneuvers for dodging enemy fire. The best pilots threw that manual out the window. Sometimes… literally. The best way to survive in the sky was to be unpredictable, to go where your target doesn’t suspect you will.
Evasive Maneuvers.name: Evasive Maneuvers

Exousia Parser.flavor: We could use data pulled from the Exousia Marauders to improve another unit's targeting capabilities—but the damn tech was so fickle. A strong breeze could scramble the signal and taking a real hit just shut it all the way down.
Exousia Parser.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Items/ExousiaParser" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="IfNotDamagedThisTurn">
			<conditions>
				<unit ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
					<notDamagedThisTurn/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<accuracy add="2"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Exousia Parser.name: Exousia Parser

Experimental Drugs (Berserk).flavor: You pass the drugs along to your soldiers. Who knows what the effect might be? The limited testing you’ve done implies the treatment can be extremely beneficial—if used by experts in controlled circumstances. You’re not sure that your militants count as experts or that a mutated alien horrorscape is anything but the opposite of a controlled environment.
Experimental Drugs (Berserk).rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" icon="Traits/Pharmaceutics" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onTraitRemoved>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="OnRemoval">
						<effects>
							<changePlayerToOwner/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
					<modifier visible="0">
						<effects>
							<movement add="100"/>
							<actionPoints add="100"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers> 
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTraitRemoved>
</trait>
Experimental Drugs (Berserk).name: Experimental Drugs (Berserk)

Experimental Drugs.flavor: You pass the drugs along to your soldiers. Who knows what the effect might be? The limited testing you’ve done implies the treatment can be extremely beneficial—if used by experts in controlled circumstances. You’re not sure that your militants count as experts or that a mutated alien horrorscape is anything but the opposite of a controlled environment.
Experimental Drugs.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Traits/Pharmaceutics" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<effects>
				<attacks mul="0.2"/>
				<damage mul="0.2"/>
				<invulnerableDamageReduction add="0.2"/>
				<movement add="1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
	<onTraitRemoved>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="OnRemoval">
						<effects>
							<hitpointsFromMax add="-0.2"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers> 
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTraitRemoved>
</trait>
Experimental Drugs.name: Experimental Drugs

Extortive.flavor: The Chieftess wasn't stupid. She knew most leaders wouldn't give her a cent when she came calling. But she liked rattling her saber on the fences, looking for those who grew complacent at her demands. When they kept ignoring her… she knew they were vulnerable for a strike.
Extortive.name: Extortive

Extra Plating.flavor: We didn't put high-caliber plating on mobile armor to get our people home safe. We did it because if we kept them alive for even a few seconds longer, they'd have the time to fire off a shot that could turn the tide of battle.
Extra Plating.name: Extra Plating

Eye of Phinnicus.flavor:
It only takes an hour to extract and secure his receptors. Minutes later you're cracking open the doors to all of ICAR's lost treasure.

Phinnicus knew the end was coming and thought he could escape it. He counted on any survivors he met being too desperate to do anything but serve him like a piece-of-shit god-king. But you've slain monsters and cracked machines in your path to survival. Now you've shattered his throne, and will gladly salvage it for spare parts.
Eye of Phinnicus.name: Eye of Phinnicus

Eye of Phinnicus (Damaged).flavor:
In the gore, you can see that his eyes were replaced with augmented receptors. Your mind flashes—those had to be how he accessed ICAR's top-secret vaults. You reach down and yank out the surviving eyeball, hardly flinching at the small shock you feel.

It's damaged—but with some light repairs, it still may open some doors for you. You curl a fist around it. Phinnicus is dead. And anyone who tries to replace him—you'll blow their brains out too.
Eye of Phinnicus (Damaged).name: Eye of Phinnicus (Damaged)

Old Painless.flavor: The Watchmaker Yetunde delivered three code-locked boxes to the Fallen Soldier, saying they were gifts from “a mutual friend.” The first box carried blueprints for faster, meaner heavy machine guns. The message that came with it dripped with delight for violence: “Let hot lead spew from the maw of the great dragon, and may your enemies drown in a nightmare of molten metal.”
Old Painless.name: Old Painless

Ablative Growth.flavor: The Watchmaker Yetunde delivered three code-locked boxes to the Fallen Soldier, saying they were gifts from “a mutual friend.” The third box left for him contained bone-metal that… healed itself? Like it was organic matter. It was impossible. “Your fallen flesh has a final form,” the final note read. “You are the first step in bringing humanity to the stars…”
Ablative Growth.name: Ablative Growth

Fervent Strength.description: Does not suffer from reduced accuracy while below 50% hitpoints
Fervent Strength.flavor: The bodies of Uzhodai's most fervent worshippers were molded for long journeys in the black of space. What did that mean? Pour a thousand bullets into one, get the bone to start sticking out from the skin, and you could see up close how the tendrils of nerves and blood vessels rebound themselves to keep the body alive and fighting. There was no wounding these monsters. Just killing them.
Fervent Strength.name: Fervent Strength

Fire.flavor: Word spread quickly about the Battle of Castaic Plain. Our forces staged an assault to take control of a water reserve from the enemy. Shots were fired. The wind was high. The ground dry as kindling. Inside of an hour, a wildfire surrounded both armies. They should have stopped fighting—worked together to douse the flames. But instead hundreds were killed and the fresh water poisoned, never to be drunk again.
Fire.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" icon="Traits/OnFire" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<conditions>
				<unit>
					<notCargo/>
					<noTrait type="Flying"/>
					<noTrait type="Hovering"/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<movementCost min="100"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
	<onTurnStarted>
		<tile>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers endure="0">
					<modifier effectDescription="EachTurn">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<notCargo/>
								<noTrait type="Flying"/>
								<noTrait type="Hovering"/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<weaponDamage weapon="Fire"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</tile>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
Fire.name: Fire

First Aid Drone.flavor: Can't give a drone a doctorate but you can give it a few hundred CCs of morphine, a pack of bandages and just enough programming to know which one to use. Most of the time, of course…
First Aid Drone.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Actions/FirstAidDrone" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onTurnStarted>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers endure="0">
					<modifier effectDescription="EachTurn">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<ally/>
								<trait type="Biological"/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<hitpoints add="2"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
First Aid Drone.name: First Aid Drone

Flesh Tree.flavor: I nearly walked away the day we decided to use these as a food source. But one smart logistics officer pinned me down with the math. If we camped by one of these trees, we could feed our people for a month. I asked them not to tell me if it turned out to be human meat.
Flesh Tree.rawXML:
<trait icon="Features/FleshTree" visibleOnTile="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="EachTurn">
			<effects>
				<food add="2"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForControllingCity">
			<effects>
				<food mul="0.2"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
	<onTurnStarted>
		<tile>
			<area affect="TilePlayer" sendNotification="1">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="Every10Turns">
						<conditions ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
							<turn divisible="10"/>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<addPlayerAction type="FleshTree" charges="1"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</tile>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
Flesh Tree.name: Flesh Tree

Flying.description:
Unaffected by terrain
Can move through enemy non-flying units and vice versa
Ignores zone of control of enemy non-flying units and vice versa
Cannot be hit by melee weapons of non-flying units
Has an extremely elevated position in line of sight calculations
Flying.flavor: Getting skybound put you in the polluted air, but it let you traverse the bleak seas and jagged cliffs that defined the cracked Earth. The view was probably better before our planet became a poisoned nightmare.
Flying.name: Flying

Fishery Wing.flavor: Some Techs who deserved a hell of a pay bump developed a chemical solution that would clean up fertilizer from the water. That made the area around our greenhouses some of the most unpolluted places on the surface. Schools of fish would gather in these spots, eager for fresh conditions—and giving us some desperately-needed food supplies to keep our people fed.
Fishery Wing.name: Fishery Wing

Forest.description: <style color='GUI/Green'/>3%<style color='Default'/> chance for forests to spread in swamp terrain
Forest.flavor: The last day I ever thought of the forest as “safe,” I was camped up by a creek, scratching out battle plans in the dirt. Then there was the “crack” of a branch. I was too slow to react—my spotter was cut down by gunfire from the opposite bank. There was no solace in the trees after that. Only a thousand rustling branches that disguised the sound of enemy movement.
Forest.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Features/Forest" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForLargeGroundUnits">
			<conditions>
				<unit>
					<trait type="Large"/>
					<noTrait type="Flying"/>
					<noTrait type="Pathcutter"/>
					<noTrait type="Titan"/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<movementCost add="1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForNonAgileGroundUnits">
			<conditions>
				<unit>
					<noTrait type="Agile"/>
					<noTrait type="DozerBlade"/>
					<noTrait type="Flying"/>
					<noTrait type="Pathcutter"/>
					<noTrait type="Titan"/>
				</unit>	
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<movementCost add="1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForNonLargeGroundUnitsAgainstRangedWeapons">
			<conditions>
				<unit>
					<noTrait type="City"/>
					<noTrait type="Flying"/>
					<noTrait type="Large"/>
				</unit>
				<weapon ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
					<noTrait type="Melee"/>
					<noTrait type="TitanMelee"/>
				</weapon>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<coverDamageReduction add="0.33"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Forest.name: Forest

Foundation of Blood.flavor: People were just tools, to the Artificer. You’d hope a good craftswoman would learn to love her tools, but she never developed such attachments. I warned her once that objects could be replaced, but people couldn’t. She disagreed. Violently.
Foundation of Blood.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Actions/FoundationOfBlood" visibleOnCity="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<conditions>
				<building>
					<production greater="0"/>
				</building>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<production mul="0.333"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier requiredUpgrade="FoundationOfBloodUpgrade">
			<conditions>
				<building>
					<production greater="0"/>
				</building>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<production mul="0.167"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier requiredUpgrade="FoundationOfBloodUpgrade2">
			<conditions>
				<building>
					<production greater="0"/>
				</building>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<production mul="0.167"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Foundation of Blood.name: Foundation of Blood

Fortification.flavor: Walls didn't make you feel safe. They just felt like a ticking clock. Every “thud” of cannonfire hitting a fortification was a countdown to when the enemy would inevitably break through. You could shore them up, patch them as best you could—but any way you sliced it, all walls were meant to fall.
Fortification.name: Fortification

Fortress Armament.description: City has an additional long-range weapon
Fortress Armament.flavor: The Emulated Mind was a particularly paranoid leader. She wanted to make sure ZEPHON or anyone else couldn't harm her. So she crafted a special cannon—never shared its specs with any other faction. It packed a hell of a punch—but I don't think she ever realized it also put a huge target on her back.
Fortress Armament.name: Fortress Armament

Fragility of Flesh.flavor: The ZEPHON chatbot’s information was good—upon the death of the enemy, the rest of your dream floods back. You watch yourself from the outside, being consumed by the- by the dreams. And you learn. You learn the fragility of flesh, the way a bloom of meat is beautiful, the way you can take it apart. You will never look at a living creature with the same eyes again.
Fragility of Flesh.name: Fragility of Flesh

Frenzy.flavor: It wasn’t surprising that desperation could turn anyone into a killing machine. It was surprising that some fighters seemed to relish it. Outnumbered? Outgunned?
