That didn’t matter to them. Banding up with these berserkers might keep you alive—but they were just as likely to get you killed.
Frenzy.name: Frenzy

Eremite Cells.flavor: The Tribunal revived an Old World tradition for those entering the Sealed Hermitage. After the cultists were sent in, attendants would pump a combination of algal gasses and toxic dust into the Hermitage as friends and family watched and wailed. Maniacal laughter and blood-curdling screams both sang from the walls within. Consecration? Funeral? I stopped caring what they called it and just tried to block out their cries.
Eremite Cells.name: Eremite Cells

Fusion Warhead.flavor: “Let me get this straight,” our chief weapons engineer said to me. “The tactical nuclear missile needs to do *more* damage? Is 50 kilotons not enough?” I really didn't feel like arguing. I showed her recon photos of a prototype Titan we'd be fighting within weeks. She gawped at the size. “Against that?” I replied. “50 kilotons is definitely not enough.”
Fusion Warhead.name: Fusion Warhead

Gladial Emanator.flavor: The Watchmakers were the first ones to design the Emanator—and the Watchmakers were the ones who destroyed most of them. This made it so much easier to kill, and those overprincipled recluses couldn't stomach what they'd created.
modifiers: - +2 Group Members Hit At Half Accuracy
Gladial Emanator.name: Gladial Emanator

Gland Harvest.flavor: Sacrifice is a fact of life under the eye of the Tribunal. Your people will gladly die to save their leader. You need only gather enough to do so…
Gland Harvest.name: Gland Harvest

Gluttony.flavor: I used to have sympathy for the finer tastes of the Honorable Aristocrat and his people. In time I grew furious with the waste. He'd never budge on how he portioned food—always making sure fine dishes were available to all. Rationing was an afterthought. Maybe there was a history there. A time in the old world when all he could eat was gruel. Perhaps… I was too harsh the last time I spoke to him.

Gravitational Compression.flavor: The Earth pulls against larger objects with greater force and with new technology available to us, we could make its might our own. The bigger our enemies came, the louder the noise they made when crashing to the ground.
Gravitational Compression.name: Gravitational Compression

Graviton Jammer.flavor: Our weapons researchers learned by accident that gravitons could be altered to create a disorienting effect. The sensation of your inner organs floating was described as “intensely unpleasant.”
Graviton Jammer.name: Graviton Jammer

Gravity Field.flavor: Sure, if a Tessera Core crushes you with the force of gravity itself, you're probably having a bad day. But you know who had a worse day? Me. I had to spend thirty minutes explaining to a Hashmallim Host why saying “gravity's a bitch” is good comedy. Machines have no sense of humor…
Gravity Field.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" icon="Features/GravityField" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<effects>
				<movementCost min="100"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
	<onTurnStarted>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers endure="0">
					<modifier effectDescription="EachTurn">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<notCargo/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<weaponDamage weapon="GravityField"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
Gravity Field.name: Gravity Field

Hammerhead Protocols.description: Only attacks when provoked if neutral
Hammerhead Protocols.flavor: Why did ZEPHON make a weapon that would never shoot first? Was it to teach us a lesson? Were we an experiment? For all we knew this could have been a happy accident, something it was content to let our best minds puzzle over.
Hammerhead Protocols.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
        <modifier>
            <effects>
                <canCaptureOutposts add="1"/>
            </effects>
        </modifier>
		<modifier visible="0">
			<conditions>
				<player>
					<faction name="Neutral"/>
				</player>
				<unit>
					<trait type="Leashed"/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<attackScore max="0"/>
				<canOverwatch add="-1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
	<onUnitAttacked>
		<defender>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="ToAttackedEnemy">
						<effects>
							<addTrait type="HammerheadTarget" duration="2"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</defender>
	</onUnitAttacked>
</trait>
Hammerhead Protocols.name: Hammerhead Protocols

Hammerhead Target.flavor: A code-savvy commando once dumped a Hammerhead CPU after a firefight. She told me that these drones build themselves a little feedback loop where each attack sends data back about the target’s vulnerabilities, and it’s able to calibrate its munitions after every attack. Don’t let them get too many shots in.
Hammerhead Target.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="FromHammerheads">
			<conditions>
				<targetUnit ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
					<type name="Hammerhead"/>
				</targetUnit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<damageTaken mul="0.333"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Hammerhead Target.name: Hammerhead Target

Ha'sharet Exchange.description: Grants access to rare Cyber items at  The Concordat
Ha'sharet Exchange.flavor: Weird message from The Concordat came in. “We are pleased to learn you have crossed the Hasharet threshold” it cooed over the comms terminal. Machines in our command center began flickering—it was transmitting a code as we spoke. “You now have access to cyberware we held in reserve for those truly seeking to… transcend.”
Ha'sharet Exchange.name: Ha'sharet Exchange

Haunted.flavor: You have no-one to talk to about this. You suppress the dream with the tools at hand—degrading as they are—knowing it will recur. Your sleep does not improve, you become pallid and disturbed and you swear that your aides—are they loyal? You swear that your aides whisper.
Haunted.name: Haunted

Headquarters.description: Destroying the headquarters unit destroys the entire city
Headquarters.flavor: Defending the heart of a city took a certain kind of grit. If you saw action while stationed here, there’d be no running. This job was for the stubborn and the stupid—those who’d rather die than lose pride in defeat.
Headquarters.name: Headquarters

Doomed Spotters.flavor: There was a quick, cheap way to improve the accuracy of headquarters' missile defenses: recon troops that could radio enemies' positions. But soldiers sent out there were at the mercy of… any number of horrors. So we found those already condemned to death and offered them a deal: endure a tour on the perimeter and their sentence would be commuted. I can count the number of survivors on one hand.
Doomed Spotters.name: Doomed Spotters

House on the Borderland.flavor: In the cellars underneath our headquarters, we found a cabin, sitting in a dank, empty chamber. If you followed the Voice cultists inside you'd find a single room furnished with the forgotten belongings of an old man. The cultists would dig at the cracks in the floor, where Algae grew alongside the mold. And if you looked out the window, you saw not the walls of a cellar, but the color-shifting sky of another world.
House on the Borderland.name: House on the Borderland

Cysilical Growths.flavor: The manufacturing plants for Chips were constructed with direct hookups to the central computers at headquarters. Data from the machine flowed out to the factories—it was the only way to mimic ZEPHON's network. But the Chips sent something back. We began finding glowing packets of silicone growing around headquarters. While we were making Chips, the Chips… were making something too.
Cysilical Growths.name: Cysilical Growths

Accelerated Gestation.flavor: The midwife's harsh words made me doubt the decision we made. “Pregnancy is already body horror,” she coldly told us. “Mothers see their appendages swell. Ligaments and teeth will loosen. Rashes will consume the skin. And you want to speed that process up?” Telling her it was a mere 17 percent increase did nothing to change her mood.
Accelerated Gestation.name: Accelerated Gestation

Heartfelt Loss.flavor: I wish I'd had the heart to teach the Romantic about the harsh reality of leadership. The Romantic knew how to keep spirits high in his troops, but he never seemed to grasp how far they could fall. When you cherish and love the soldiers around you, their loss—or the threat of their loss—will hurt even harder.
Heartfelt Loss.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<effects>
				<moraleLoss add="0.25"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier requiredUpgrade="HeartfeltLossUpgrade">
			<effects>
				<moraleLoss add="-0.1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier requiredUpgrade="HeartfeltLossUpgrade2">
			<effects>
				<moraleLoss add="-0.1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Heartfelt Loss.name: Heartfelt Loss

Part Distribution.flavor: The Artificer smiled at me as she hooked up a damaged ZEPHON core to the Synthetic Printer network. “You see old friend,” she said, ignoring the machine’s violent electronic klaxons. “Integrating this core will increase the production speed of our printers. But really… I just wanted to hear the sound of ZEPHON's scream.”
Part Distribution.name: Part Distribution

Transuranic Apathy.flavor: “I designed a machine wielding the power of a god, and you're telling me you haven't produced one yet because of… safety protocols?” I was surprised that anyone serving the Heartless Artificer still cared about worker safety. This poor engineer that she screamed at did his best. But it was obvious by then: nothing could get in the way of her precious “progress.”
Transuranic Apathy.name: Transuranic Apathy

Heavy.flavor: Heavier weapons needed time to set up and calibrate a targeting solution. Firing them while on the move was a hell of a gamble. Some unlucky troops could find themselves addicted to those long odds. The smart ones knew how to play it safe for a sure shot.
Heavy.name: Heavy

Hero.flavor: Good generals knew the danger of letting anyone stand out from the crowd. Our soldiers needed to be faceless, so they could die and we would feel little. But some soldiers defied that logic. They rose from the muck to become key pieces on the battlefield. Losing them always hurt the most.
Hero.name: Hero

Hexeskeltal Creche.flavor:
The Hexeskeltal Creche is one of your finest inventions. All of the contours of this unique laboratory are designed to channel the alien energies into your waiting vessel.

The comet nears its approach. You've taken to calling it Hwedo's Comet—some part of you still has fondness for the creation myths of old Earth. Its appearance in the sky has alarmed the other great powers, and driven nearby bands of survivors into a panic.

They've all noticed the construction of your lab, and demanded you explain its purpose. When you ignored them, they began massing forces to destroy it.

Your machines flicker and whirr as Hwedo's Comet approaches. The experiment has already begun—now you can devote your efforts to ensuring nothing stops it.
Hexeskeltal Creche.name: Hexeskeltal Creche

Hijack.flavor: After we began deploying mechs, tanks, and other heavy armor, I thought the Chieftess would keep her distance. I was an idiot. The Reavers followed her for a reason. She knew a good pillaging opportunity when she saw one, and knew how surprised we'd be to see her Reavers bearing down on us with our own machines.
Hijack.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" icon="Actions/Hijack" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onUnitDisappeared>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier>
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<enemy/>
								<noTrait type="Headquarters"/>
								<noTrait type="Titan"/>
								<trait type="Large"/>
								<trait type="Mechanical"/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<killCargo/>
							<changePlayer/>
							<hitpointsFromMax min="0.25"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onUnitDisappeared>
</trait>
Hijack.name: Hijack

Hit and Run.flavor: In the Operative's old life, every moment spent standing still was one where the authorities could finally catch up with her. I thought we'd argue more about her criminal past, but I was forced to admit, her old habits were… well tuned for winning this war. Maybe soldiers and thieves have more in common than they say.
Hit and Run.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForActions">
			<effects>
				<consumedMovement max="0"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier effectDescription="IfNotMoved" requiredUpgrade="HitAndRunUpgrade">
			<conditions>
				<unit>
					<notMovedThisTurn/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<attacks mul="0.1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier visible="0" requiredUpgrade="HitAndRunUpgrade2">
			<conditions>
				<unit>
					<availableAction name="Move"/>
					<attackedThisTurn/>
					<notMovedThisTurn/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<movementMax add="1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
	<onUnitAttacked>
		<attacker>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="AfterAttackingIfNotMoved" requiredUpgrade="HitAndRunUpgrade2">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<notMovedThisTurn/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<movement add="1"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</attacker>
	</onUnitAttacked>
</trait>
Hit and Run.name: Hit and Run

Holopatter.flavor: Oldest trick in war is covering yourself in branches so it's harder to see you in the forest. The techs cooked up holographic cloaks that also worked well in dense ruins. Couldn't keep you hidden forever, but bought you a few extra seconds to line up the perfect shot. Don't need to hide if the thing you're shooting is dead.
Holopatter.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForNonLargeNonFlyingUnitsWhenAttackingFromForestsOrRuins">
			<conditions>
				<unit>
					<noTrait type="Flying"/>
					<noTrait type="Large"/>
				</unit>
				<unit ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
					<trait type="Forest"/>
					<trait type="Ruin"/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<accuracy mul="0.167"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Holopatter.name: Holopatter

Holy Bond.flavor: Artillery slammed into our bunker and everything went white. Thought that was it. But for a second I saw—was it a bridge? A hand reaching for me? And then the smoke cleared. We were still standing, and an Akavish Provost lumbered above our unit. “YOUR TIME IS NOT UP!” it shrieked. “THE ONE ABOVE CALLS FOR YOUR BLADES!” The grunts around me cheered and charged. I just stood there… still feeling the brush of that outstretched hand on my palm.
Holy Bond.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Actions/HolyBond" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<effects>
				<invulnerableDamageReduction add="0.167"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
	<onWeaponDefended>
		<traitSourceUnit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="ToSourceUnit">
						<effects>
							<weaponDamage triggerEffects="0" useAttackerWeapon="1" factor="0.167"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</traitSourceUnit>
	</onWeaponDefended>
</trait>
Holy Bond.name: Holy Bond

Well-Fed.flavor: “A chief… nutritionist?” I was stunned. But the Aristocrat said I could accept it or find a new boss. His theory was that a dedicated food scientist managing our supply lines could ensure every soldier ate a meal that maximized their job function. And I'll be damned if it didn't work. I certainly ate better fighting for him.
Well-Fed.name: Well-Fed

Treasures of Life.flavor: “The saplings and seeds are from my family estate,” the Aristocrat told me. I'd asked him how his farms produced so much food. Figured there was fancy biotech at the other end of it. He seemed sad as he shared more details. “The fields were beautiful. Trees and gardens tended with care for centuries… gone now. I had to make sure not all of their beauty was lost.”
Treasures of Life.name: Treasures of Life

Honor-bound.flavor: The Aristocrat could be a pain in the ass, but he was one of the few grifters in the wastes who was looking out for you. If you signed a trade deal with him—even a bad one—he sung your praises to the markets, made you look like a respectable partner. Make deals like that, and you'll bring plenty of friends close. And your enemies won't know they're in your net until it's too late.
modifiers: - +1 Influence Per Trade Agreement For Both Parties
- +2 Influence Per Alliance For Both Parties
- +50% Influence Per Trade Agreement For Both Parties
- +1 Influence Per Alliance For Both Parties
- +50% Influence Per Trade Agreement For Both Parties
- +1 Influence Per Alliance For Both Parties
Honor-bound.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnPlayer="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<effects>
				<influencePerTradeAgreement add="1"/>
				<influencePerAlliance add="2"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier requiredUpgrade="HonorboundUpgrade">
			<effects>
				<influencePerTradeAgreement add="0.5"/>
				<influencePerAlliance add="1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier requiredUpgrade="HonorboundUpgrade2">
			<effects>
				<influencePerTradeAgreement add="0.5"/>
				<influencePerAlliance add="1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Honor-bound.name: Honor-bound

Horizon Expansion.flavor: “Expansion.” They were already so proud of themselves for conjuring black holes on Earth and now they wanted to “expand the event horizons.” They weren't expanding anything. They were pulling us closer to the end of the universe itself.
Horizon Expansion.name: Horizon Expansion

Horrifying.flavor: Fear was supposed to keep you alive. But how could you fight for survival if all you could perceive was blood rushing through your ears? It could claw at you, drag you down and leave you helpless—the perfect victim for a creature that hungered for your blood.
Horrifying.name: Horrifying

Air Freightnet.flavor: Wasn't really anything like an “airport” anymore so we had cargo jets fly in and out of military airfields. Had a nice side effect: get even a few regular flights going between bases and everyone from merchants to well-wishing families came rushing in to squeeze extra cargo into your hangar. Gave people a sense of… normalcy, I guess.
Air Freightnet.name: Air Freightnet

Itinerant Recruiters.flavor: The armies of the old world left plenty of lessons for us in the new one. To bring in more soldiers, we dispatched recruiters to our poorest communities—not to conscript, but to entertain. To make promises. To tell lies that would bring the desperate to our doorsteps. Plenty of those recruits became great soldiers. Far more made for useful cannon fodder.
Itinerant Recruiters.name: Itinerant Recruiters

Old Access Protocols.flavor: We were in danger of losing access to the remaining satellite networks—no way we could keep up with all the AI crawling across the earth. One hacker in our ranks had a solution: she scrapped all our old access protocols, built new commands using programming languages so old no other techs knew about them. “The whole world used to hang on shit like this,” she said. The AI could never crack it.
Old Access Protocols.name: Old Access Protocols

Labor Union.flavor: One frustrating day, an explosion rocked one of our key factory lines. The error was human in nature—but with all the workers in the room dead, we had no idea if it was sabotage or a simple mistake. It was cold calculus that led us to replace the workers with machines—fully automating our factories. There was a heavy price to pay. We made clear we lost trust in their loyalty. And they would make clear: they'd lost trust in our leadership.
Labor Union.name: Labor Union

Hunger of Hwedo.flavor: The beast can be sated—if you are willing to sacrifice your own people.
Hunger of Hwedo.name: Hunger of Hwedo

Hungering Circlet.flavor: Followers of the Voice would gladly strap these metal monstrosities to their heads. When they bled, the band would tighten against their skulls and give them the fury of a berserker. Some used them to become better fighters. But I could tell others wore them because they loved the pain.
Hungering Circlet.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Items/HungeringCirclet" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="IfDamagedThisTurn">
			<conditions>
				<unit ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
					<damagedThisTurn/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<attacks mul="0.333"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Hungering Circlet.name: Hungering Circlet

Hovering.description:
Can move over water
Unaffected by roads, rivers and Bleed
Hovering.flavor: The tactical purpose of low-level flight is to launch assaults over normally impassable terrain. But there was a morale value too. All beings, organic or mechanical, seemed to take thrill cruising so near to the ground.
Hovering.name: Hovering

Hwedo's Brain.flavor:
Your heart races—Hwedo's brain is alive. The consciousness captured from beyond the stars is now contained in your laboratory.

This is the beginning of your great work. No body you constructed before capturing the comet's energy could have properly contained the intelligence within. Now when you finish the war… you will have all the time in the world to build a better one.

You will have time to create the perfect life form.
Hwedo's Brain.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" visibleOnPlayer="1">
	<onTurnStarted>
		<traitSourcePlayer>
			<modifier effectDescription="Every5Turns">
				<conditions ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
					<turn divisible="5"/>
				</conditions>
				<effects>
					<singularityCores add="3"/>
				</effects>
			</modifier>
		</traitSourcePlayer>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
Hwedo's Brain.name: Hwedo's Brain

Hymn of Decay.flavor: When I first felt the toxic touch of this tortured hymnal I assumed there was a strategic reason for poisoning the earth like this. But after so many battles… there had to be more to it. Was it spiritual? Or was it an act of childish spite? I imagined doomed aliens lashing back at our world for daring to resist their apocalyptic mission. The thought chilled me to the bone.
Hymn of Decay.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" icon="Actions/HymnOfDecay" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onTurnStarted>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers endure="0">
					<modifier effectDescription="EachTurn">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<notCargo/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<weaponDamage weapon="HymnOfDecay"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
					<modifier effectDescription="EachTurn" requiredUpgrade="AfflictionsAntiphon">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<notCargo/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<morale add="-2"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>					
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
Hymn of Decay.name: Hymn of Decay

Leaden Rain.flavor: Boss was like a kid in a candy store when she learned ICAR Corp had been experimenting with railguns in its Icarus Satellite Network. “Metal rod? Down from sky? YES! NOW.” I swear that woman was feral. “Like ScreamTroopers 5, loved that game. I LOVED. That game.”
Leaden Rain.name: Leaden Rain

Ignores Cover.flavor: There’s nothing more frightening than when you realize the wall you thought was keeping you safe just made you a bigger target.
Ignores Cover.name: Ignores Cover

Immobilized.flavor: Our enemies pinned me down on the battlefield on plenty of occasions. I've been injured, trapped by the Bleed, frozen with strange technology, you name it. I watched good soldiers panic in those moments—they tried to make peace with their gods, begged for mercy, or fight like hell to escape. When I was trapped like that, all I could think was “there is still work to be done.” That's how I made it this far. There is still so much to do.
Immobilized.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForMeleeWeapons">
			<conditions>
				<weapon match="Any">
					<trait type="Melee"/>
					<trait type="TitanMelee"/>
				</weapon>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<attacks max="0.0"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier>
			<effects>
				<movementMax max="0.0"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Immobilized.name: Immobilized

Immobilizing.flavor: Our enemies pinned me down on the battlefield on plenty of occasions. I've been injured, trapped by the Bleed, frozen with strange technology, you name it. I watched good soldiers panic in those moments—they tried to make peace with their gods, begged for mercy, or fight like hell to escape. When I was trapped like that, all I could think was “there is still work to be done.” That's how I made it this far. There is still so much to do.
Immobilizing.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnWeapon="1">
	<onWeaponAttacked>
		<defender>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="ToNonTitanEnemy">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<noTrait type="Titan"/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<addTrait type="Immobilized" duration="1"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</defender>
	</onWeaponAttacked>
</trait>
Immobilizing.name: Immobilizing

Immoral.flavor: The Artificer knew her actions would repulse people. She had no interest in how others thought of her. Perhaps she literally couldn't. But they followed her anyway—followed her burning-bright vision of the future.
Immoral.rawXML:
<trait rankMax="19" rankPerTurn="1" visibleOnCity="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<conditions>
				<building>
					<type name="Headquarters"/>
				</building>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<loyalty addMin="-0.5" addMax="-10"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier requiredUpgrade="ImmoralUpgrade2">
			<conditions>
				<building>
					<type name="Headquarters"/>
				</building>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<loyalty addMin="0.25" addMax="5"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Immoral.name: Immoral

Incandescent Icon.flavor: One of the most powerful weapons created in our AI research looked like a humble lantern—but the light it gave off did far more than illuminate. It hosted intelligent photons that could be programmed to recognize friend from foe. Just passing through a field of them could irritate the skin, and extended exposure was hell on flesh and armor alike.
Incandescent Icon.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Items/IncandescentIcon" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onTurnStarted>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit" radiusMin="1" radiusMax="1">
				<modifiers endure="1">
					<modifier effectDescription="ToAdjacentEnemyUnitsEachTurn">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<notCargo/>
								<enemy/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<weaponDamage weapon="IncandescentIcon"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
Incandescent Icon.name: Incandescent Icon

Independent.flavor: The Rogue Operative liked surrounding herself with free-thinkers and loudmouths—people who wouldn't hesitate to speak their minds. A crew like that wasn't as loyal as true soldiers, but the Operative was fine with that. She didn't need sycophants—she needed the best the wasteland had to offer. That was her path to victory.
Independent.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnCity="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<effects>
				<populationLoyaltyUpkeep mul="0.25"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier effectDescription="IndependentUpgrade" requiredUpgrade="IndependentUpgrade">
			<conditions>
				<city>
					<population less="7"/>
				</city>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<populationLoyaltyUpkeep mul="-0.25"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier effectDescription="IndependentUpgrade2" requiredUpgrade="IndependentUpgrade2">
			<conditions>
				<city>
					<population greater="6"/>
					<population less="13"/>
				</city>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<populationLoyaltyUpkeep mul="-0.25"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Independent.name: Independent

Indirect Fire.flavor: Firing without line of sight meant putting faith in a higher power. Maybe it was a computer. Maybe the Voice. You were in a duel with something you could not see, and you needed all the help you could get.
Indirect Fire.name: Indirect Fire

Inevitable End.flavor: A Cr'la worshiper was talking my ear off about how he could see “the threads of life” that “connected every person to this mortal coil.” I was being an ass, asked if he could cut those threads and save us a heap of trouble. He reached out, pulled at something floating over my head and I hit the ground, choking. “I can,” he said. “Oh, I can indeed.”
Inevitable End.name: Inevitable End

River Port.flavor: The rushing rivers were still the best way to trade goods and share news—merchant crews and haulers moved much faster when they glided on the water's surface. We wanted word of our strength to spread across the land—and word travels fastest on the lips of sailors bound for the nearest tavern.
River Port.name: River Port

Interference Protocols.flavor: Machines do what you tell them to do, not what you want them to do. With the right programming, you could tell your enemy’s machines all kinds of interesting lies. They’d think up was down, friend was foe, and light was dark. Of course, enemy techs worked to counteract that programming, so it wasn’t a silver bullet. But it made it easier to dodge their shots for a short period of time.
Interference Protocols.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" icon="Actions/InterferenceProtocols" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<effects>
				<accuracy mul="-0.5"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier requiredUpgrade="CryptoFetters">
			<effects>
				<movementMax mul="-0.333"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier requiredUpgrade="EmulatedMindAffinityUpgrade">
			<effects>
				<accuracy mul="-0.167"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>		
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Interference Protocols.name: Interference Protocols

Internal Repair Station.flavor: A group of aspiring young technicians came to me with a plan to install repair stations in our Marauder transports. Their superiors pushed back—called it a waste of time. I pointed out that there are plenty more spare parts close to the battlefield—and if the senior techs were so eager to run repairs, they could be assigned elsewhere. They relented.
Internal Repair Station.rawXML:
<trait icon="Actions/InternalRepairStation" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onTurnStarted>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers endure="0">
					<modifier effectDescription="EachTurn">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<noType name="ExousiaMarauder"/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<hitpoints add="2"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
Internal Repair Station.name: Internal Repair Station

Iok'la.flavor: Iok'la. Just saying the word makes your skin crawl. Damn freaks just said it was “a word made flesh.” And what an emphasis on flesh. It was green, leathery and wrapped itself around you to give you just a bit more… body. I hated picking one up. But every time I did, I was able to stay in the fight longer and longer.
Iok'la.name: Iok'la

Judgement From Above.flavor: “Judgment from above.” The only ones in need of judgment were whatever dipshit commander put their armies on lower elevation than an artillery unit. Techs wanted to babble about hypermechanical bullshit when they saw how hard our unit got hit but there wasn't anything more to it than simple physics. But hey, no one listens to me anyway…
Judgement From Above.name: Judgement From Above

KENAZ.flavor:
How do you fool an all-knowing, all-seeing artificial intelligence? “We'll give it exactly what it wants,” Hopper says. She duplicates every shard you uncover and sends the copies back to ZEPHON.

Soon, she networks together the captured shards, and now you have it—your own AI. Hopper names it “KENAZ.”
KENAZ.name: KENAZ

Kind.flavor:
These once proud destroyers, reduced to pitiful wretches. You hope their salvation also means yours, so you give the Acrin enough resources to sustain themselves and repair their critical systems.

Your soldiers assist the aliens and the work is completed swiftly. Afterward the Acrin line up and walk by your forces individually, giving each a swooping gesture that begins and ends at their eyes, before returning to their compound.

A day later the Anchorite contacts you. Tales of your kindness spread throughout the Acrin enclaves, and those you saved wish to live near you permanently.
Kind.name: Kind

Knife of the Chieftess.flavor:
When you arrive at the rendezvous point the Chieftess stands alone, arms crossed and with a grim look in her eyes. Why does she have no guards?

You say nothing as your troops haul Jezina forward. The Chieftess draws a curved knife, then gently drags it across Jezina's cheek. “I could press harder,” she whispers. “Draw the smallest bit of blood, just like you used to.”

Jezina is shaking. The Chieftess raises the blade—and then throws it at your feet. “Your payment,” she says. “Now go. This is a family matter.”

You quickly return to your vehicle. You wonder if that sound you hear is the wind blowing over the wasteland—or Jezina whimpering in terror.
Knife of the Chieftess.name: Knife of the Chieftess

Large.flavor: Bigger creatures and machines could take a pounding, but they grew weaker the more parts of them you stripped away.
Large.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier visible="0">
			<conditions ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
				<targetUnit>
					<noTrait type="Swallower"/>
				</targetUnit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<cargoSlotsRequired min="-1" max="-1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Large.name: Large

Large Splash.flavor: Some of our enemies thought they could overwhelm us with numbers—like ants, they'd swarm over our territory in a bid to drag us down. How beautiful it was, when we realized we could squash them beneath our boots—wipe out so many irritating creatures with one strike.
modifiers: - +4 Group Members Hit At Half Accuracy
Large Splash.name: Large Splash

Laser.flavor: Nothing poetic in using light as a weapon. All light is a weapon. The sun burns the body, the floodlight breaks your cover and the dim bulb of an interrogation chamber can break your mind. Laser tech was at least honest. It told you what it was going to hit — and more importantly, where it was coming from.
Laser.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnWeapon="1">
	<onWeaponAttacked>
		<weapon>
			<modifier effectDescription="ToNonLowPowerWeapon">
				<conditions ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
					<weapon>
						<noTrait type="LowPower"/>
					</weapon>
				</conditions>
				<effects>
					<addTrait type="LowPower" duration="2"/>
				</effects>
			</modifier>
		</weapon>
	</onWeaponAttacked>
</trait>
Laser.name: Laser

Lawful.flavor: Honestly, you’re relieved to see the drugs go up in flames. As are those in your city. Everyone understands the temptations presented by those materials and are pleased that the decision has been taken out of their hands.
Lawful.name: Lawful

Leashed.description:
Stays within the perimeter
Overwatches but does not necessarily attack on its turn
When attacked will be unleashed along with any nearby allies
Leashed.flavor: Want to stare death in the face? Find the home of a particularly nasty predator. Take a long walk around its territory and wait until the hairs go up on the back of your neck. Keep on your side of the line. Make eye contact with your stalker and feel your heart pump faster and faster. That's the bridge between this world and the next.
Leashed.name: Leashed

Leave No Man Behind.flavor: The Fallen Soldier's obsession with death made him so eager to keep every one of his troops alive. But devotion has its costs. Every life you save, every rogue soldier you bring in from the wastes, is another mouth to feed. He should never have been so… sympathetic. I considered it his sole weakness.
Leave No Man Behind.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<conditions>
				<unit>
					<noType name="Deformity"/>
					<noType name="LandanGraham"/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<unitUpkeep mul="0.3"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier requiredUpgrade="LeaveNoManBehindUpgrade">
			<conditions>
				<unit>
					<noType name="Deformity"/>
					<noType name="LandanGraham"/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<unitUpkeep mul="-0.1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier requiredUpgrade="LeaveNoManBehindUpgrade2">
			<conditions>
				<unit>
					<noType name="Deformity"/>
					<noType name="LandanGraham"/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<unitUpkeep mul="-0.1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Leave No Man Behind.name: Leave No Man Behind

Life Steal.flavor: You couldn’t steal souls. But some creatures fed on them—your life force would become a battlefield snack, an MRE for the monstrous. I thought everyone was fighting to survive. But this brave new world of ours gave birth to a new kind of predator: one with a taste for the spark of survival.
Life Steal.name: Life Steal

Lifestyle Implants.flavor: I thought gathering around a table for a meal with friends was what made this war worth fighting for. But when the nutrient implants came in, people were so eager to abandon the mess halls, instead snacking between shifts on rocks, metal… dirt. I ate alone. I didn't even want to throw away the shitty taste of the MREs.
Lifestyle Implants.name: Lifestyle Implants

Liquid Deflection Augment.flavor: The Operative’s troops couldn’t dodge every shot. She turned her attention to reducing the brunt of the blows. “Be like water,” a great master once said. With some experimentation, she could make that a… literal improvement.
Liquid Deflection Augment.name: Liquid Deflection Augment

Logistics Experts.flavor: Supplies being hauled back from the outposts always had a habit of “falling off the back of the truck.” Command got tired of the losses and ordered us to round up experts who could monitor each shipment. They were ruthless. If they supervised your shift you weren't getting a wink of sleep until each piece of metal was hauled out of the earth and accounted for.
Logistics Experts.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Actions/LogisticsExperts" visibleOnTile="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<effects>
				<flatResourcesFromOutposts mul="4.0"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier requiredUpgrade="AssetStripping">
			<effects>
				<flatResourcesFromOutposts mul="1.0"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Logistics Experts.name: Logistics Experts

Low Power.flavor: You had to get used to the rhythm of using a laser weapon. Shoot. Recharge. Repeat. Just one, two , three—like you were learning how to dance. Shoot, recharge, repeat. Shoot, recharge, repeat. Shoot… recharge… repeat…
Low Power.name: Low Power

Performance Broadcasts.flavor: Our hologram library had maybe a few dozen films on file. Command worried the troops would get bored or be driven to mutiny if we played them on a loop. But in hard times, everyone just wanted a good story. Something to make sense of the world.
Performance Broadcasts.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Actions/LoyaltyUpgrade" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onTurnStarted>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers endure="0">
					<perBuildingInCityModifier effectDescription="LoyaltyUpgrade">
						<perBuildingConditions>
							<building>
								<type name="Loyalty"/>
							</building>
						</perBuildingConditions>
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<ally/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<morale add="1"/>
						</effects>
					</perBuildingInCityModifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
Performance Broadcasts.name: Performance Broadcasts

Machine Evolution.flavor:
The world is no longer humanity’s alone. The corruption of the Voice seeps into both humans and Acrin—but not the machine. Perhaps this new artificial life is the edge you need to win.

You task your splicer drones with accelerating their evolution. The neo genesis is a huge success. Your new artificial citizens join your city, and their unique minds make them peerless scientists.

Just after your new digital citizens settle in, an explosion destroys one of their blocks. A group of your seasoned troops claim responsibility and go rogue. Now you must stop their senseless rampage.
Machine Evolution.name: Machine Evolution

Machine Rights.flavor:
The world is no longer humanity’s alone. The relentless drive of ZEPHON threatens all life on Earth—but could it have evolved differently?

Your city’s most brilliant minds study these new lifeforms to determine whether they possess not just intelligence, but consciousness. The labs in your city are filled with their tireless experimentation.

The effort is a huge success. Your new artificial citizens integrate easily into your society. There’s surging optimism about the future, but the study exhausts your resources. You’ll need to redouble efforts in any stalled projects, but there are now many more eager to help.
Machine Rights.rawXML:
<trait icon="Traits/AreMachinesAlive" visibleOnCity="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForConstructionYard">
			<conditions>
				<building>
					<type name="Construction"/>
				</building>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<production add="-1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier>
			<conditions>
				<building>
					<type name="Headquarters"/>
				</building>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<loyalty add="1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Machine Rights.name: Machine Rights

Machine Tools.flavor:
Have we learned nothing from our past mistakes? While we know their design, the mind of the machine is as alien to us as the Acrin. Why risk creating a future threat?

You task your Hacker-Jackers to cut into the machines and erase the errant code responsible for their burgeoning autonomy. One of them prioritized speed over software integrity and the machines in their research lab go berserk, razing the compound before escaping the city to continue their rampage.

The other machines are successfully processed to become tireless—and now unwavering—construction tools.
Machine Tools.rawXML:
<trait icon="Traits/AreMachinesAlive" visibleOnCity="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForConstructionYard">
			<conditions>
				<building>
					<type name="Construction"/>
				</building>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<production add="1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier>
			<conditions>
				<building/>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<research mul="-0.1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Machine Tools.name: Machine Tools

Marked Target.flavor: When you're in the thick of combat, having eyes on a ridge above, calling out targets helps a hell of a lot. Puts a nice rhythm in things. Mark the target. Set the target. Execute the target. o
Marked Target.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" icon="Actions/MarkTarget" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<opponentModifiers>
 		<modifier effectDescription="AgainstThisUnitWithRangedWeapons">
 			<conditions ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
 				<weapon>
 					<noTrait type="Melee"/>
					<noTrait type="TitanMelee"/>
 				</weapon>
 			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<accuracy add="2"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</opponentModifiers>
</trait>
Marked Target.name: Marked Target

Market Economy.flavor: The profit incentive is driving the avaricious in your society to find even more innovative ways of making themselves richer. That’s resulted in a boom in patents and inventions, many of which deal with the many people starving and sleeping in the streets. Obviously, amongst the poorest, your name is mud.
Market Economy.name: Market Economy

Masochism.flavor: “The fuck are you doing?!” I remembered shouting at one of those damned Epicureans as it walked right over our trench, soaking up a spree of bullets that weren't set to hit anything. “Calm yourself… mentor,” it said. How did it… it didn't have a face but I swear it was smiling at me. “We both know pain is a constant. You run from it…” It jerked as another round of bullets ripped into its shoulder. “I savor it.”
Masochism.name: Masochism

Massive Splash.flavor: Time slowed as a massive explosion loomed over us like a tidal wave. A wave the size of a building that heaves over your ship and prepares to plunge it to the depths. At least those caught in the blast died quicker than the slow torment of death by water.
modifiers: - +6 Group Members Hit At Half Accuracy
Massive Splash.name: Massive Splash

Mechanical.flavor: You know what’s funny? People make machines to solve complicated problems. But on the battlefield, a machine becomes a problem to solve. Sometimes it took special skills to bring them down. Sometimes you just needed a bigger machine.
Mechanical.name: Mechanical

Melee.flavor: I know in the old world, humans would craft arts and disciplines of this kind of combat. But it all boiled down to the same thing: a burst of adrenaline and swing of a weapon did more to keep you alive than—forms, or sparring, or made-up ranks. Every living being knows how to hurt another—you just have to get close enough to make it happen.
Melee.name: Melee

Microchip Fabricator.flavor: ZEPHON's microchip manufacturing process relied on a decentralized network. There was a brief period where we thought capturing enough of these fabricators would draw its attention. But why would it care? If one fabricator went offline, it could manufacture a new one a safe distance away, its production queue barely interrupted.
Microchip Fabricator.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Features/MicrochipFabricator" visibleOnTile="1" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onTurnStarted>
		<tile>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers endure="0">
					<modifier effectDescription="ForStationedMechanicalUnitEachTurn">
						<conditions ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
							<unit>
								<trait type="Mechanical"/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<hitpoints add="2"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</tile>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
Microchip Fabricator.name: Microchip Fabricator

Militant Legion.flavor: “There's strength in numbers, and survival of one depends on the survival of many.” I couldn't argue with the old veteran telling me to centralize our forces. Isolationism killed his people off one by one out in the wastes. He saw what I couldn't, that the world was coming together again for a war unlike anything we ever knew.
Militant Legion.name: Militant Legion

Military Background.description: Starts the game with an Outrider
Military Background.flavor: The Fallen Soldier's memories may have been scrambled when he first woke up but all his fighting instincts were intact. When it came time to scout the wastes, he knew digging up an Outrider would do more good than having grunts crawling through the darkness. It gave him an edge—just the barest edge—in the early days of the war.
Military Background.name: Military Background

Parthian Equilibrium.flavor: The Fallen Soldier could be so particular about military history. If you cracked open his journals, you would find notes to himself like “cavalry tactics—useful with Outriders?” He believed in the great leaders who came before him. I urged him to balance their words carefully, and find a way to forge his own path.
Parthian Equilibrium.name: Parthian Equilibrium

Stacked Mines.flavor: The Watchmaker Yetunde delivered three code-locked boxes to the Fallen Soldier, saying they were gifts from “a mutual friend.” The second one read “Punish any who dare stalk your trail. Leave them limbless and screaming in the dirt.” Inside the box… plans for stackable mines.
Stacked Mines.name: Stacked Mines

Amigara Exploration.flavor: I did everything I could to avoid the cliffside dig sites. Passing through a canyon riddled with holes… I couldn't help but feel like something was calling to me from them. Something that wanted me to crawl deep into the planet's core and find a new kind of peace. Did the Aegyllan Worms feel that same presence? Or was this… something else?
Amigara Exploration.name: Amigara Exploration

Mines.flavor: Outrider operators knew when the bullets started flying, they weren’t combatants: they were bait. Their job was to lay mines in key positions and lure the enemy in. Then once the trap was sprung, they could burn rubber and get away—and whatever was hunting them became easy pickings for the rest of us.
Mines.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" icon="Actions/Minelayer" visibleOnUnit="1" visibleSourcePlayer="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForEnemyGroundUnits">
			<conditions>
				<unit>
					<enemy/>
					<noTrait type="Flying"/>
					<noTrait type="Hovering"/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<movementCost min="100"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
	<onTileEntered>
		<tile>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="WhenEnemyGroundUnitStopsOnTile">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<notCargo/>
								<enemy/>
								<noTrait type="Flying"/>
								<noTrait type="Hovering"/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<weaponDamage weapon="Mines"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
			<area affect="Tile">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="WhenEnemyGroundUnitStopsOnTile">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<enemy/>
								<noTrait type="Flying"/>
								<noTrait type="Hovering"/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<removeFeature type="Mines"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</tile>
	</onTileEntered>
</trait>
Mines.name: Mines

Mysticism.flavor: The witches of the Tribunal were kind enough to not kill the first scientists who questioned their mystic knowledge. But they issued a clear ultimatum: The Voice's word was not to be questioned. Any heresy would be met with death. Techs and researchers in their ranks heard them loud and clear. The smart ones defected—and the sycophants stayed.
Mysticism.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnBuilding="1" visibleOnCity="1" visibleOnPlayer="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForResearchLaboratory">
			<conditions>
				<building>
					<type name="Research"/>
				</building>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<research add="-2"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForAdministrationComplex" requiredUpgrade="MysticismUpgrade">
			<conditions>
				<building>
					<type name="Influence"/>
				</building>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<research add="1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForAdministrationComplex" requiredUpgrade="MysticismUpgrade2">
			<conditions>
				<building>
					<type name="Influence"/>
				</building>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<research add="1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Mysticism.name: Mysticism

Nanomachine Accelerator Augment.flavor: The Operative was quite comfortable with the creation of… certain performance enhancements. On machines and biologicals alike, she could boost stamina and speed with the help of nanomachines. Her troops couldn’t move much faster but they could get a hell of a lot farther.
Nanomachine Accelerator Augment.name: Nanomachine Accelerator Augment

Neumanatic Cornucopia.flavor: The NeoDuke's tongue slips, and they spill the secret of an artifact in their possession: the Neumanatic Cornucopia. The one-of-its-kind device was a pre-war prototype for printing food using only raw matter. It could ensure the end of aching bellies among your people.
Neumanatic Cornucopia.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" visibleOnPlayer="1">
	<onTurnStarted>
		<traitSourcePlayer>
			<modifier effectDescription="Every5Turns">
				<conditions ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
					<turn divisible="5"/>
				</conditions>
				<effects>
					<food add="30"/>
				</effects>
			</modifier>
		</traitSourcePlayer>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
Neumanatic Cornucopia.name: Neumanatic Cornucopia

Nightmare.description:
Only visible to you and allies
Kills unit when duration runs out
Nightmare.flavor: Intel could never keep up with how many Phenaris Hunters were out on the battlefield. They weren't breeding, they were just… I don't know. Pulling a version of themselves in from another dimension? Fooling everyone, even the machines? I don't know. Too many monsters and too many tricks to keep in my head. I just wanted to rest…
Nightmare.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" icon="Actions/Nightmare" visibleOnUnit="1" visibleToNonAllies="0">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<effects>
				<deathMorale max="0"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
	<onUnitDefended>
		<defender>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="WhenTakingDirectDamage">
						<effects>
							<hitpointsFromMax add="-1.0"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</defender>
	</onUnitDefended>
	<onTraitRemoved>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier>
						<effects>
							<removeUnit/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers> 
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTraitRemoved>
</trait>
Nightmare.name: Nightmare

Nuclear Fallout.flavor: Heh. Everyone talks about ZEPHON and the Acrin ravaging the Earth but… we flirted with the apocalypse, didn't we? Men who couldn't make it to orbit brought civilization to the edge of oblivion. Generations later, we still use their weapons and the Earth still burns at their passage.
Nuclear Fallout.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" icon="Features/NuclearFallout" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onTurnStarted>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers endure="0">
					<modifier effectDescription="EachTurn">
						<effects>
							<hitpoints add="-4"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
Nuclear Fallout.name: Nuclear Fallout

The Mind's Eye.flavor: When I was a young fool, gossip went around; of a scientist, a genius, who died attempting to fulfill that old billionaire dream of living forever by uploading herself. It didn’t work, of course-the giant machine was inert, unmotivated, left operating as a curiosity. Until ZEPHON found it and brought that mind to life, focusing its will as a weapon against the invading Acrin. In time, its—I should say, ‘her’—her will could stretch for miles, a thought could snuff out an enemy half a world away. A good reason not to gossip anymore…
The Mind's Eye.name: The Mind's Eye

Extinction.flavor: If “Oblivion's” power was like gaining control of lightning, “Extinction” was mastering the entire storm. The Emulated Mind became a god of old, perched atop her mountain, hurling depleted uranium across the land like thunderbolts. Children are taught to fear such gods. We had to learn how to serve one.
Extinction.name: Extinction

On Fire.flavor: I dreamed frequently of being set aflame. Every time it came I felt my nerves erupt with pain, then disintegrate into nothingness. Did you know all noise fades into this thin crackling as your eardrums burn away? Every time I thought I'd forgotten the sensation, it would come again. I knew it was no dream. Someone… somewhere, wished me to be bound in flame.
On Fire.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onTurnStarted>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers endure="0">
					<modifier effectDescription="EachTurn">
						<effects>
							<hitpoints add="-3"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
On Fire.name: On Fire

Oppressive.flavor:
Zandra is a dangerous inspiration. Your other scientists begin championing their pet projects over the ones you appointed. Each thinks they have the key to victory, none are concerned with the costs.

You need to make an example of her. Zandra shouts as your enforcers drag her into the streets. She begs the gathering scientists to activate her machine as she’s locked into an iron hollow. No one responds, but many openly glare at you. The next day, strikes occur across your labs and key projects stall.

While progress is merely slowed, any misstep can be fatal in the race for survival.
Oppressive.name: Oppressive

Outpost.flavor: If you're going to hold your ground, find the right ground to hold. Years of wars and scavenging left plenty of defendable positions scattered across the battlefield. When the enemy was breathing down your neck and you needed a space to make your stand, you ran for spots like these.
Outpost.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForNonLargeGroundUnitsAgainstRangedWeapons">
			<conditions>
				<player>
					<noFaction name="Neutral"/>
				</player>
				<unit>
					<noTrait type="City"/>
					<noTrait type="Flying"/>
					<noTrait type="Large"/>
				</unit>
				<weapon ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
					<noTrait type="Melee"/>
					<noTrait type="TitanMelee"/>
				</weapon>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<coverDamageReduction add="0.167"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>	
		<modifier effectDescription="ForAlliedUnits">
			<conditions>
				<player>
					<noFaction name="Neutral"/>
				</player>
				<unit>
					<ally/>
					<noTrait type="City"/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<cityDamageReduction add="0.167"/>
				<healingRate mul="0.5"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>	
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Outpost.name: Outpost

Overcharged.flavor: We learned early how to pop off the Gauss safeties—just click the switch three times and hold it down. Then came the glowing fumes that made us all high as kites. Finally the front line grunts had real power. Even the burns that came with it felt so, so good.
Overcharged.name: Overcharged

Overheating.flavor: There were no safety protocols in war. We discovered otherworldly new forms of energy and used them to fuel devastating weapons and machines. Push any of them past their limit and the energy would break containment, burning their operator. Sometimes that was the price of victory. Often it was just a waste.
Overheating.name: Overheating

Particle Barrier.flavor: No other shielding behaved the way the Krypt Archai’s Particle Barrier could. Shields normally needed a power source—I lost too many soldiers trying to keep that power online. These barriers… they just… worked. Maybe the particles were the power source? Drawing energy from within and clustering to catch incoming fire? It was… otherworldly.
Particle Barrier.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Features/ParticleBarrier" rankMax="2" visibleOnTile="1" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="AgainstRangedWeapons">
			<conditions ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
				<weapon>
					<noTrait type="Melee"/>
					<noTrait type="TitanMelee"/>
				</weapon>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<invulnerableDamageReduction addMin="0.25" addMax="0.75"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Particle Barrier.name: Particle Barrier

Particle Interference.flavor: The Krypt Archai's particles would stick with a target even if it got away. They wouldn't inflict injury, but they were viciously engineered to interfere with any healing or repair efforts. The Archai it seemed, wanted its victims to linger in pain.
Particle Interference.name: Particle Interference

Particle Interfering.flavor: The Krypt Archai's particles would stick with a target even if it got away. They wouldn't inflict injury, but they were viciously engineered to interfere with any healing or repair efforts. The Archai it seemed, wanted its victims to linger in pain.
Particle Interfering.name: Particle Interfering

Pathcutter.description: Reduces  movement cost of forests and ruins
Pathcutter.flavor: A wide-beam AI array, mounted on a prototype drone. Useless for combat, as it takes an hour to warm up. You set it up, point it where you want to go, and flip the safety off. Then cover your ears to its howl and follow. It finds impossibly perfect way through the most tangled jungle, plant or urban, paths you can never find again.
Pathcutter.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Items/Pathcutter" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<effects>
				<movementMax add="4"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
	<onTraitRemoved>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier visible="0">
						<effects>
							<movement add="-4"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTraitRemoved>
</trait>
Pathcutter.name: Pathcutter

Penance.flavor: Oh those Provosts didn't respect their commanders any more they did the troops around them. Their resource needs were astronomical, but if you tried to mitigate them they'd lash out at you. “The price for our service is HIGH,” they'd roar through blown-out speakers. They bent the knee, but demanded a high price to do so.
Penance.name: Penance

Perimeter Range.description: Can target units on or adjacent to city tiles
Perimeter Range.flavor: Trial, error, and too many dead scouts helped us clock just how far ZEPHON's energy defenses could reach. Get too close to the city and you'd be pulverized. If Command had just given us artillery from the start, we could have saved so many lives…
Perimeter Range.name: Perimeter Range

Phantasm.flavor: Dreameaters belonged to another world. They'd just been pulled through to slaughter people in ours. Sometimes you'd fire three rounds into one… and watch the last bullet pass right through like they were just air.
Phantasm.name: Phantasm

Phase Fontead.flavor: These devices starting appearing out of nowhere in storage rooms and gunner kits. I volunteered to be the lab rat and find out what it was. I activated one and felt what seemed like electricity flowing through my veins. I shot faster and hit harder than anyone in my unit—but I also had this constant sense of deja vu. Like I'd lived all this before. Like I'd live it all… again?
Phase Fontead.name: Phase Fontead

Phase Generator.flavor: The first time I crossed paths with a Watchmaker, she was running maintenance on one of these generators. We… argued about who should be allowed to control them. “You're here to win a war. I'm here to stop the next one,” she said. We cut a deal. If we funneled some energy to the Watchmakers, they'd activate the shielding to protect our people.
Phase Generator.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Features/PhaseGenerator" visibleOnTile="1" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onWeaponDefended>
		<attacker>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="ToAttacker">
						<effects>
							<weaponDamage triggerEffects="0" useAttackerWeapon="1" useDefenderUnit="1" factor="0.333"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</attacker>
	</onWeaponDefended>
</trait>
Phase Generator.name: Phase Generator

Philosopher's Stone.flavor:
The stone is jagged, with wide facets, and feels pleasantly cold in your hand. Underneath its dark surface, something that resembles the alien algae blooms in slow, hypnotic patterns.

As you study it, you hear a whispering voice that turns into a thousand screams. Power, they promise, power for blood. You need power. But, thinking of the bandit leader, you decide it’s too risky to use yourself—but that’s why you have lieutenants.
Philosopher's Stone.name: Philosopher's Stone

Pilgrim of the Voice.flavor: The last step to becoming a true disciple of Cr'la was a days-long journey through the wastes. No food. No water. No protection from the sun, the Bleed, or anything else. When they returned and were ready for the field, their six feet would bleed this filthy yellow gunk, shredded by debris that cut deep into their bleached flesh.
Pilgrim of the Voice.name: Pilgrim of the Voice

The Plague, Full Lockdown (Failure).flavor: Your troops seal the city centres off, confining people to their homes or—worse— workplaces, enforcing the curfew brutally. For what seems like an eternity, the city sweats under your measures… to little avail. The virus survives despite your totalitarian touch and the population loses all faith in you.
The Plague, Full Lockdown (Failure).name: The Plague, Full Lockdown (Failure)

The Plague, Full Lockdown (Success).flavor: Your troops seal the city centres off, confining people to their homes or (worse) workplaces, enforcing the curfew brutally. For what seems like an eternity, the city sweats under your measures… and survives. You might not be popular anymore—or even liked—but you console yourself that the viral strain is eliminated.
The Plague, Full Lockdown (Success).name: The Plague, Full Lockdown (Success)

The Plague, Middle Measures (Failure).flavor: ‘Halfway there is nowhere’, as the idiom goes. And the city is nowhere, miserable under your measures, despondent both with your authoritarianism and your lack of commitment to it. The graffiti on the fortress walls reads ‘give me ennui or give me death’—but you managed to give them both and the virus continues to spread.
The Plague, Middle Measures (Failure).rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" icon="Traits/ThePlague" visibleOnCity="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<conditions>
				<building>
					<type name="Headquarters"/>
				</building>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<growth add="-3"/>
				<loyalty add="-3"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
The Plague, Middle Measures (Failure).name: The Plague, Middle Measures (Failure)

The Plague, Middle Measures (Success).flavor: You implemented a frankly half-hearted mix of science and superstition. You can’t quite believe it worked—it made no sense, went against all the science—but the city seems to be clear of the virus, with only a small number of deaths. You aren’t loved by any means, but you’ve minimized all the worst possible scenarios, and kept your job—for now.
The Plague, Middle Measures (Success).rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" icon="Traits/ThePlague" visibleOnCity="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<conditions>
				<building>
					<type name="Headquarters"/>
				</building>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<growth add="-1.5"/>
				<loyalty add="-1.5"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
The Plague, Middle Measures (Success).name: The Plague, Middle Measures (Success)

The Plague, Open Business (Failure).flavor: The clown doesn’t laugh any more. He doesn’t jape as he is rolled in, doesn’t blink as the flies walk across his glassy stare, doesn’t flinch as the soil falls onto his painted smile. His audience, spread about him, raise no applause, arms slack at their sides. The bulldozer buries them all. The shops, businesses and theatres are all open and fizzing with life, though it is mainly flies and maggots by now.
The Plague, Open Business (Failure).name: The Plague, Open Business (Failure)

The Plague, Open Business (Success).flavor: The clown doffs his blonde wig on stage and does another turn, pratfalling and spraying foam across the front seats. The applause is quieter than before—but how could it not be, given the number of empty seats and empty streets and empty houses and full graves? But those who remain are very much entertained.
The Plague, Open Business (Success).name: The Plague, Open Business (Success)

Planned Economy.flavor: Your citizens respect your dedication to their well-being and a certain proportion look at you as a great helmsman of the state, pledging their unshakeable loyalty to you personally. Others agree but think you’re spinning the wheel of state randomly and that you’re possibly drunk at the helm.
Planned Economy.name: Planned Economy

Poisoned.flavor: Dragoons would drag their spears through the vile waste the Abkluth left behind after defecating. The tips of their weapons would then be coated in some of the most vile and dangerous substances ever exposed to human skin.
Poisoned.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onTurnStarted>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers endure="0">
					<modifier effectDescription="EachTurn">
						<effects>
							<hitpoints add="-3"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
Poisoned.name: Poisoned

Collective Conduit.flavor: One of those damned Watchmakers appeared out of nowhere during a power shortage to give us plans for this—toy. It was like a puzzle box with glowing lights, somehow sensitive to the user's mood. If you were relaxed—no, *happy*—and playing with it… the damn thing would generate power. The first time I took one home, I swear I caught a glimpse of someone—or something—watching me out of the corner of my eye.
Collective Conduit.name: Collective Conduit

Perpendicular Trancing.flavor: Vile. Inhuman. Treating people like meat just to save space. Putting people side-by-side on cots, sure, that's how you get through hard times. But stunning and hanging them? Like beef in a freezer? Anyone who uses this tech is damned to hell.
Perpendicular Trancing.name: Perpendicular Trancing

Power Spike.flavor: The techs plastered the Vulkan manuals with all kinds of restrictions. Vulkan pilots knew how and why to break them. If you overcharged the power past its limits, you’d blow out whole pieces of the Vulkan. But in exchange you could fuel that power into all of the Vulkan’s weapons. Risking that extra damage was a gamble but it paid off frequently.
Power Spike.name: Power Spike

Relics of Eld.flavor: The Concordat hated bargaining with the Practical Romantic. He'd wander into their tents and give their agents hell—always knew what items were the real deal. Could pick out the junk, the fakes, and shame them into haggling on the knockoffs. “Amateurs,” he'd mutter. “I grew up stealing from smarter shopkeepers.”
Relics of Eld.name: Relics of Eld

Her Infinite Variety.flavor: Tech wasn't the Romantic's specialty—but I caught him one day scribbling improved shielding formulas for our champions. “She whispered to me in my dream,” he muttered. “A queen of the old world, the old continent. She…” He trailed off and kept writing. I don't think long-dead royals were the ones sharing advanced technology through the power of dreams.
Her Infinite Variety.name: Her Infinite Variety

Prey.flavor:
You urge your people to endure the Dreameater, hopeful that another solution will present itself in time.

As the monster continues to leave its gifts throughout your city, rumors begin to surface that you’re responsible for creating it, that it’s your dark patron, that you are the creature—for what other reason could there be for your passivity?

Then the rumors boil into unrest. Buildings are vandalized, their parts used to fuel bonfires that burn throughout the night. The bonfires do little to deter the Dreameater, but the people find comfort in the destruction—comfort that you failed to provide.
Prey.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" icon="Traits/TheGreatHunt" visibleOnCity="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<conditions>
				<building>
					<type name="Headquarters"/>
				</building>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<growth add="-3"/>
				<loyalty add="-3"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Prey.name: Prey

Profuse Propagation.flavor: If Ioks weren't sent out to die they'd breed forever. Cultists whispered about how they had to keep the population in check—but some pushed the limits. What was the harm in breeding one or two more monsters to win the war? Still, even with one more popping out in a swarm… it still seemed to make the skies all the more darker.
Profuse Propagation.name: Profuse Propagation

Pulling.flavor: Like watching old movies on the lazy boy. The hero gets dragged to certain doom and their lover dives in, to save ‘em. ‘Cept I’m watching a house-sized Abkhan, all muscle and teeth, and a Voice Titan is pulling it in, munching on it like popcorn. And I ain’t doing shit to save it.
Pulling.name: Pulling

Quarry Feed.flavor: What ZEPHON's Titan saw, all machines saw. The ones nearby at least. And they clambered to get close to it… connecting to its network, linking to all the other machines—it was the only time I saw them experience what humans feel singing together around the campfire, or in a church: euphoria.
Quarry Feed.name: Quarry Feed

Quid Pro Quo.description: Grants abilities to efficiently purchase food, minerals or energy with influence
Quid Pro Quo.flavor: Everyone was always squirreling away food. The Aristocrat was the only one who could get people to part with it. It was like the old fable about a savior who could feed his followers with an infinite supply of bread and fish. If that savior was real, maybe he and the Aristocrat spoke the same language—the language of mutual aid and survival.
Quid Pro Quo.name: Quid Pro Quo

Raiders.flavor: Had the bad luck to be held prisoner in a Reaver camp once. I watched them gather like flies around a corpse, fighting for scraps and even killing each other as the camp grew too crowded. When everyone seemed ready for mass murder, that's when the Chieftess sent them out on the hunt.
Raiders.name: Raiders

Reaver Advancement.flavor: The Chieftess was manic, but savvy. Ran circles around us, stealing our gear, distracting us from her scheming. Always stepped her game up another notch. You'd think she and her Reavers were outmatched… and then one would sneak up on you, yank your advanced helmet off, and slit your throat.
Reaver Advancement.rawXML:
<trait category="Upgrade" icon="Factions/Chieftess" rankMax="9" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<conditions>
				<unit>
					<noTrait type="Headquarters"/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<damage mulMin="0.05" mulMax="0.5"/>
				<hitpointsMax mulMin="0.05" mulMax="0.5"/>
				<unitCost mulMin="0.1" mulMax="1.0"/>
				<unitUpkeep mulMin="0.1" mulMax="1.0"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier>
			<conditions match="Any">
				<action>
					<type name="ProduceUnit"/>
				</action>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<productionCost addMin="1.2" addMax="12.0"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier visible="0">
			<conditions>
				<unit>
					<noTrait type="Headquarters"/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<strength mulMin="0.1" mulMax="1.0"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Reaver Advancement.name: Reaver Advancement

Trash Camo.flavor: One trooper I bunked with—long, grey-haired fellow who read too many books—called these new camo suits “a ghillie suit for the end times.” Laden with what looked like junk, but was actually high-tech adaptive camo. We used it to nestle into the crevices of downed machines, looking like little more than rusted pieces of our dying civilization.
Trash Camo.name: Trash Camo

Ghost Corps.flavor: Old world corpos strung governments along with promises of AI that would “synergize” infantry units. Like all that other AI crap, it was a bunch of junk. The Rogue Operative somehow got it working for cybernetic ground troops. Just needed troops with a little less free will…
Ghost Corps.name: Ghost Corps

Close-Quarters Fire.description: <style color='GUI/Green'/>+100%<style color='Default'/>  attacks at half range
Close-Quarters Fire.flavor: Only undisciplined idiots sprayed bullets over long distance. You wanted to do maximum damage? Then you had to let them get close. Real close. And then you squeezed that trigger for dear life.
Close-Quarters Fire.name: Close-Quarters Fire

Reactive Trigger.flavor: Armor penetrating rounds ain’t cheap. But plenty of defenses are weak if you pound them with repeating fire or trigger any reactive armor. A simple device that sprayed tracer rounds before a main attack just lets you punchthrough a bit easier.
Reactive Trigger.name: Reactive Trigger

Recycling Tanks.flavor: Disgusting stuff. Voice cults eking out a pathetic living in the wastes built these facilities to manufacture more Algae. No need to build graveyards when you could just dump bodies and viscera into a toxic pit that turned out a vile meat slush. I kept a particle mask on while visiting sites like this.
Recycling Tanks.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Features/RecyclingTanks" visibleOnTile="1" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onTurnStarted>
		<tile>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers endure="0">
					<modifier effectDescription="ForStationedBiologicalUnitEachTurn">
						<conditions ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
							<unit>
								<trait type="Biological"/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<hitpoints add="2"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</tile>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
Recycling Tanks.name: Recycling Tanks

Regeneration.flavor: Sometimes I'd overhear scientists debating how creatures from the Acrin homeworld could heal so efficiently. They'd debate if we could use it to save human lives—or extend them. I made clear if they ever learned how to recreate this healing factor, that we would first use it for our troops before the civilian populace. I worried we would have too many mouths to feed.
Regeneration.name: Regeneration

Exobiology Station.flavor: It took some time, but our researchers came up with methods and processes to safely study creatures and plants from off-world. They requested the construction of dedicated stations for such research. We had to invest in them. Bringing such creatures into our regular facilities often had fatal outcomes.
Exobiology Station.name: Exobiology Station

Resource Network.flavor: The Emulated Mind must have connected to some ZEPHON database in her exposure to the net. She had detailed inventories available of all outposts we encountered—her scouts could leave no stone unturned, bring home every resource hidden from prying eyes. It was one of the few upsides of her painful genesis.
Resource Network.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnPlayer="1" visibleOnTile="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<conditions>
				<tile>
					<trait type="Outpost"/>
				</tile>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<flatResourcesFromOutposts mul="1.0"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier requiredUpgrade="ResourceNetworkUpgrade">
			<conditions>
				<tile>
					<trait type="Outpost"/>
				</tile>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<flatResourcesFromOutposts mul="0.25"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier effectDescription="WhileAlliedNonFlyingUnitOnTile" requiredUpgrade="ResourceNetworkUpgrade2">
			<conditions>
				<tile>
					<trait type="Outpost"/>
				</tile>
				<unit>
					<ally/>
					<noTrait type="Flying"/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<flatResourcesFromOutposts mul="2.0"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Resource Network.name: Resource Network

Revealed.flavor: Oh there was so much to learn when you peered out into the darkness. The Voice had its way of finding secrets and the AI had their own. But all of us went looking out in the world for the same reason—to survive, to grow and to see our enemies before they could see us.
Revealed.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" rankFromAction="0" visibleOnUnit="1" visibleSourcePlayer="1">
	<onTraitAdded>
		<tile>
			<area affect="Tile">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier>
						<effects>
							<reveal/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
