				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</tile>
	</onTraitAdded>
	<onTurnStarted>
		<tile>
			<area affect="Tile">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier visible="0">
						<effects>
							<reveal/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</tile>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
Revealed.name: Revealed

Revealing.flavor: Oh there was so much to learn when you peered out into the darkness. The Voice had its way of finding secrets and the AI had their own. But all of us went looking out in the world for the same reason—to survive, to grow and to see our enemies before they could see us.
Revealing.name: Revealing

River.flavor: Every predator on Earth knew that you will find your prey at their weakest when they search for water. And prey species knew that when they seek water, they risk being hunted. You'd do well to make yourself the predator, but if you find yourself as the prey, remember that crossing the rushing water will slow down most hunters.
River.rawXML:
<trait icon="Features/River" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForGroundUnits">
			<conditions>
				<unit>
					<noTrait type="Flying"/>
					<noTrait type="Hovering"/>
					<noTrait type="Titan"/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<movementCost add="1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
River.name: River

Road.flavor: The first night after we got our first roads constructed, I hopped in an Outrider and drove for miles. Burned too much gas just to feel the wind running through my hair, feeling the tires grip the asphalt as I took the turns. I didn't want to go back to the war. I just wanted to drive forever.
Road.rawXML:
<trait icon="Features/Road" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<conditions>
				<tile>
					<noFeature type="Fire"/>
					<noFeature type="Bleed"/>
				</tile>
				<unit>
					<noTrait type="Flying"/>
					<noTrait type="Hovering"/>
					<noTrait type="Titan"/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<movementCost max="0.75"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Road.name: Road

Ruins.flavor: Earth That Was. The Old World. The Before Times. There were plenty of ways to refer to life before the Acrin. None of them could sum up what it felt like to gaze at the ruins and daydream what it was like before. Soon children will be born with no memory of this place. I don't know if I envy them or not. I can't imagine fighting without this sadness in me.
Ruins.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Features/Ruins" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForLargeGroundUnits">
			<conditions>
				<unit>
					<trait type="Large"/>
					<noTrait type="Flying"/>
					<noTrait type="Pathcutter"/>
					<noTrait type="Titan"/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<movementCost add="1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForNonAgileGroundUnits">
			<conditions>
				<unit>
					<noTrait type="Agile"/>
					<noTrait type="DozerBlade"/>
					<noTrait type="Flying"/>
					<noTrait type="Pathcutter"/>
					<noTrait type="Titan"/>
				</unit>	
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<movementCost add="1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForNonLargeGroundUnitsAgainstRangedWeapons">
			<conditions>
				<unit>
					<noTrait type="City"/>
					<noTrait type="Flying"/>
					<noTrait type="Large"/>
				</unit>
				<weapon ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
					<noTrait type="Melee"/>
					<noTrait type="TitanMelee"/>
				</weapon>				
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<coverDamageReduction add="0.33"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Ruins.name: Ruins

Scavenger.flavor: The Romantic was definitely the “waste not want not,” type. I think he still was haunted by those long nights in the bunker, desperately yearning for any scrap of food or supplies that could save his people. He rarely let on, but sometimes I saw him reviewing the reports of scavenged resources and I would see this look of mourning cross his face.
Scavenger.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<effects>
				<resourcesPerKillFromCost add="0.1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier requiredUpgrade="ScavengerUpgrade">
			<effects>
				<resourcesPerKillFromCost add="0.05"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier requiredUpgrade="ScavengerUpgrade2">
			<effects>
				<resourcesPerKillFromCost add="0.05"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Scavenger.name: Scavenger

Schism of Regimina.flavor: Once, long ago, ZEPHON lent one of its creations to a band of humans close to death. Those survivors repaid its kindness by stealing the unit's access codes and trying to kill their savior. It retaliated—viciously. Now the only memory of those idiots is a hard drive carrying the codes, bought and sold on black markets with utmost secrecy. If ZEPHON learned where that drive was—it would stop at nothing to destroy it.
Schism of Regimina.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" icon="Items/SchismOfRegimina" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onTraitAdded>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier>
						<effects>
							<changePlayer changeOwner="0"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTraitAdded>
	<onTraitRemoved>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="WhenDurationRunsOut">
						<effects>
							<changePlayerToOwner/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTraitRemoved>
</trait>
Schism of Regimina.name: Schism of Regimina

Scientist Strike.flavor:
Zandra is a dangerous inspiration. Your other scientists begin championing their pet projects over the ones you appointed. Each thinks they have the key to victory, none are concerned with the costs.

You need to make an example of her. Zandra shouts as your enforcers drag her into the streets. She begs the gathering scientists to activate her machine as she’s locked into an iron hollow. No one responds, but many openly glare at you. The next day, strikes occur across your labs and key projects stall.

While progress is merely slowed, any misstep can be fatal in the race for survival.
Scientist Strike.name: Scientist Strike

Seed of Extinction.flavor: I couldn't shake that soldier's instinct. To me, the Crodeus Seeds were just another explosive to run from on the battlefield. But the barracks chatter was that the Seeds came from another world. That the Crodeus were dragging multiple dimensions together. It sounded… no more insane than anything else that Tuesday.
Seed of Extinction.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" icon="Actions/SeedOfExtinction" visibleOnUnit="1" visibleSourcePlayer="1">
	<onTraitRemoved>
		<tile>
			<area affect="Unit" radius="1">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="ToEnemyUnitAndAdjacentEnemyUnitsOnRemoval">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<enemy/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<weaponDamage weapon="SeedOfExtinction"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</tile>
	</onTraitRemoved>
</trait>
Seed of Extinction.name: Seed of Extinction

Self-Destruct.flavor: There was no escaping it. Some weapons we forged needed to kill their wielder to be effective. Troops tasked with carrying such armaments were given strict psychological screenings between missions, and drones were only dispatched on suicide runs when we could spare the resources. There's always a high price to pay with this kind of warfare—you had to make sure the payoff was worth it.
Self-Destruct.name: Self-Destruct

Sentry Protocols.flavor: Machines that wandered the wasteland didn’t care whose flag you marched under. They did care if you entered their line of sight and, if they were programmed to do so, they’d open fire without hesitation. You couldn’t even squeeze in a friendly “hello.”
Sentry Protocols.name: Sentry Protocols

Shaken.flavor: A rattled soldier was a more vulnerable soldier. If you'd seen the horrors of the wastes, your hands might tremble instinctively the next time you picked up a weapon and you'd be slow to move when enemy fire rained on your position.
Shaken.name: Shaken

Shamhurish Assistance.flavor: A group of researchers embed themselves and proceed to interrogate and investigate the divergent shard. Shamhurish is slightly annoyed at being so isolated but happy to talk to the researchers and egocentric enough to explain everything about its systems—and even comment on new technology brought to it, a huge boon to your understanding of ZEPHON’s systems.
Shamhurish Assistance.name: Shamhurish Assistance

Shamhurish Augmentation.flavor: This was a mistake—Shamhurish reveals itself as a true fragment of ZEPHON and integrates with its network, augmenting its drones. Beware facing them in the battlefield—they know each soldier’s weaknesses, destroying morale. It’s easy to break a machine—but to kill one that sobs in your mother’s voice…?
Shamhurish Augmentation.name: Shamhurish Augmentation

Shamhurish Corruption.flavor: It takes some time, but it appears that Shamhurish was true to its word, whether it intended to be or not. Though apparently swallowed by ZEPHON, it mischievously contends with the network from the inside, weakening its oversight and control systems. Soon your soldiers see ZEPHON’s drones behaving oddly in the field, drifting into your soldiers’ fire, as if being carried by great, gentle hands.
Shamhurish Corruption.name: Shamhurish Corruption

Shoulder Plate.flavor: Our techs didn't hit on this armor—the Enforcers did. One of them kicked in the door on a strategy session and unceremoniously dumped a prototype version of the armor on our war table. “Make more of these” was all he said before leaving the room.
Shoulder Plate.name: Shoulder Plate

Quantum Economics.flavor: Never try to explain quantum mechanics to a rank-and-file jarhead. You'll wind up saying something stupid like “Quantum Manipulators make other Quantum Manipulators cheaper because the Quantum Manipulator perceives the new Quantum Manipulator.” And then you'll wonder where the hell your life went this wrong.
Quantum Economics.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnBuilding="1">
	<modifiers>
		<perBuildingInOwnCitiesModifier effectDescription="SingularityCoresUpgrade">
			<perBuildingConditions>
				<building>
					<type name="SingularityCores"/>
				</building>
			</perBuildingConditions>
			<effects>
				<mineralsCost mul="-0.2"/>
				<productionCost mul="-0.2"/>
			</effects>
		</perBuildingInOwnCitiesModifier>
		<perBuildingInOwnCitiesModifier effectDescription="SingularityCoresUpgrade" visible="0">
			<perBuildingConditions>
				<building>
					<type name="SingularityCores"/>
				</building>
			</perBuildingConditions>
			<effects>
				<mineralsCost min="0"/>
				<productionCost min="1"/>
			</effects>
		</perBuildingInOwnCitiesModifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Quantum Economics.name: Quantum Economics

Skydda.flavor: Here’s a contradiction: The Valkyria operators were fixated on death, but carried shields into battle. If they sought a great death, why try to preserve their lives? There was another layer to their thinking: that death must come at the correct time and place. Shielding themselves made that day possible.
Skydda.name: Skydda

Slow Priming.flavor: These weren’t quick weapons—poor fare for sentries who needed to react at a moment’s notice. But if you had time to draw on your target, you’d hit them with a shot they’d never forget—if they lived.
Slow Priming.name: Slow Priming

Smoke Screen.flavor: I don’t know if you know this, but tanks are… big. Easy to hit. We rigged up smoke launchers on them to cover our retreats. Plenty of idiot operators thought they were invincible riding in the seat of a Crusader. The smart ones knew when to drop smoke and bug out.
Smoke Screen.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Features/SmokeScreen" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="AgainstRangedWeapons">
			<conditions>
				<weapon ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
					<noTrait type="Melee"/>
					<noTrait type="TitanMelee"/>
				</weapon>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<coverDamageReduction add="0.333"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Smoke Screen.name: Smoke Screen

Sniper.flavor: The first snipers took their name from the cruel act of shooting birds in colonized territories. Our snipers faced far more worthy prey.
Sniper.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnWeapon="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="AgainstNonLargeUnits">
			<conditions>
 				<targetUnit ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
					<noTrait type="Large"/>
				</targetUnit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<damage mul="1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier effectDescription="AgainstUnitsAtRange1">
			<conditions>
 				<targetUnit ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
					<distance equal="1"/>
				</targetUnit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<accuracy mul="-0.5"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Sniper.name: Sniper

Spirit of Mankind.flavor: Couldn't tell you if people are good or evil. But good leaders can make them good. Show your people what you'd sacrifice for them and they'll daydream of what they'd sacrifice for each other. But it never lasts. Gotta make the most of it while everyone's hearts are something close to pure.
Spirit of Mankind.name: Spirit of Mankind

Splash.flavor: Some weapons don’t just hit the target, they take out their closest friends too.
modifiers: - +2 Group Members Hit At Half Accuracy
Splash.name: Splash

Spotter Drone.flavor: The fog of war can get inside your head. If you don't know what's right in front of your face, you start to imagine all kinds of monsters waiting for you in the dark. Drones could help with that. Sometimes just seeing a little further helped our grunts keep their shit together.
Spotter Drone.name: Spotter Drone

Stealing Reavers.flavor: Some of your citizens are skeptical of the new citizens, refusing to help or hire them, and spitting as they pass. This lack of opportunity causes some of the ex-Reavers to return to their old ways, stealing to survive. Changing society is a slow process, it seems, especially where old wounds still fester.
Stealing Reavers.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" icon="Traits/TheyAreInTheWalls" visibleOnCity="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<conditions>
				<building>
					<type name="Headquarters"/>
				</building>
			</conditions>			
			<effects>
				<food add="-2"/>
				<loyalty add="-1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Stealing Reavers.name: Stealing Reavers

Stealth.flavor: Staying in the shadows could keep you safe. It also let you ambush anyone who got too close.
modifiers: - -1 overwatch attacks from targeting this unit
Stealth.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<effects>
				<canEnemyOverwatch add="-1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier effectDescription="WithMeleeWeapons">
			<conditions ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
				<weapon>
					<trait type="Melee"/>
				</weapon>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<canOverwatch add="1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Stealth.name: Stealth

Stunned.flavor: All kinds of ways to freeze up on the battlefield—sometimes it's your brain that locks up, sometimes some Voice-fueled bullshit holds your body in place. Reason doesn't matter though. Whatever's made you freeze, you just get to sit there while the world passes by and the wolves tear you apart.
Stunned.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<effects>
				<actionPointsMax max="0"/>
				<movementMax max="0"/>
				<healingRate max="0"/>
				<moraleRegeneration base="0"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Stunned.name: Stunned

Summon.description: Kills unit when duration runs out
Summon.flavor: Short-term assets put a ticking clock on your battle plans. Whether deploying Drones or Deformities, we needed to time our attack just right to maximize our firepower. Send them out too soon, and you've already lost the fight.
Summon.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier visible="0">
			<effects>
				<foodUpkeep max="0"/>
				<mineralsUpkeep max="0"/>
				<transuraniumUpkeep max="0"/>
				<energyUpkeep max="0"/>
				<antimatterUpkeep max="0"/>
				<algaeUpkeep max="0"/>
				<dimensionalEchoesUpkeep max="0"/>
				<chipsUpkeep max="0"/>
				<singularityCoresUpkeep max="0"/>
				<influenceUpkeep max="0"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
	<onTraitRemoved>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier>
						<effects>
							<removeUnit/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers> 
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTraitRemoved>
	<opponentModifiers>
		<modifier visible="0">
			<effects>
				<attackScore mul="-0.5"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</opponentModifiers>
</trait>
Summon.name: Summon

Supplication.flavor: A drunk engineer made her way down to our barracks, babbling about her work on the Provost. Talked about code written in languages she'd never seen. Functions that could command all in its presence to listen to its screeching lectures. “That's not fucking code in there,” she said between swigs of toilet ale. “That's primal. Laws of the universe shit. That machine may be closer to God than any of us ever will be.”
Supplication.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" icon="Actions/Supplication" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
 		<modifier effectDescription="AgainstNonSourceUnit">
 			<conditions ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
 				<targetUnit>
 					<notTraitSourceUnit/>
 				</targetUnit>
 			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<attacks max="0"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Supplication.name: Supplication

Survivor's Bazaar.flavor: There were plenty of opportunists, idealists, and swindlers who drew people to them in the wastelands. What always surprised me was that these canny leaders never took up arms. Some of them could have led armies to victory—instead, they brought everyone together.
Survivor's Bazaar.rawXML:
<trait icon="Features/SurvivorsBazaar" visibleOnTile="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="EachTurn">
			<effects>
				<influence add="2"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForControllingCity">
			<effects>
				<influence mul="0.2"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier>
			<effects>
				<tradeGain mul="0.1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Survivor's Bazaar.name: Survivor's Bazaar

Swallowed.flavor: The sky was that gut-sickening dark gray you get with a strong summer storm. I thought we'd won the battle. But our cheers turned to screams as lightning flashed and a Crodeus dropped through the clouds. It gulped down a whole Vanquisher tank then soared over our position. I could hear the screech of tearing metal and the screaming of the crew even over the roar of thunder.
Swallowed.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" icon="Actions/Swallow" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<effects>
				<actionPointsMax max="0.0"/>
				<movementMax max="0.0"/>
				<healingReceived mul="-1.0"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
	<onTurnStarted>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers endure="0">
					<modifier effectDescription="EachTurn">
						<effects>
							<hitpointsFromMax add="-0.2"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
Swallowed.name: Swallowed

Swallower.flavor: The sky was that gut-sickening dark gray you get with a strong summer storm. I thought we'd won the battle. But our cheers turned to screams as lightning flashed and a Crodeus dropped through the clouds. It gulped down a whole Vanquisher tank then soared over our position. I could hear the screech of tearing metal and the screaming of the crew even over the roar of thunder.
Swallower.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onUnitDisappeared>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Cargo">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="FromCargoOnDeath">
						<conditions ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
							<unit>
								<enemy/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<removeTrait type="Swallowed"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
					<modifier effectDescription="UnitsOnDeath">
						<effects>
							<disembark/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onUnitDisappeared>
</trait>
Swallower.name: Swallower

System Overload.flavor: The Krypt Archai had some kind of… universal sabotage protocol. It didn’t make any sense, drove our techs up the wall. It seemed to work on weaponry by making ammo explode, but it could play havoc with networked systems, or choke Voice weapons on their own power. What was this thing? Where did it get this power?
System Overload.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" icon="Actions/SystemOverload" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForRangedWeapons">
			<conditions>
				<weapon ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
					<noTrait type="Melee"/>
					<noTrait type="TitanMelee"/>
				</weapon>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<damageSelf addMin="0.25" addMax="0.75"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
System Overload.name: System Overload

Tactical Archeology.description: Grants access to rare Human items at  The Concordat
Tactical Archeology.flavor: A smuggler linked to The Concordat rolled up one day with an “exclusive deal.” Special access to top-tier corpo tech the traders had kept squirreled away. Had to be a catch. Why now? “Humans, the Voice, ZEPHON… only one of them will survive this war,” he said, picking something (meat?) out of his teeth. “We're all-in on humanity. Now we know you are too.”
Tactical Archeology.name: Tactical Archeology

Tactical Visor.flavor: Ishim Enforcers were the first cyborgs we created with access to networked intelligence. Our techs cooked up visors that could triangulate enemy positions by pulling data from different Enforcers together. Only problem was, you needed your troops to be close to each other for reliable targeting metrics.
Tactical Visor.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="TacticalVisor">
			<conditions>
				<unit ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
					<unitsInRange greater="0" range="1">
						<unit>
							<ally/>
							<type name="IshimEnforcer"/>
						</unit>
					</unitsInRange>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<accuracy add="2"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Tactical Visor.name: Tactical Visor

\u201cTake Cover!\u201d.flavor: I dropped behind cover on so many different battlefields that I started to get a taste for different kinds of dirt. Fresh farm soil has a wetness to it. Desert sand can lure you in with the taste of salt. And land where the Voice bled through… it made you want to spit until your mouth was dry.
\u201cTake Cover!\u201d.name: “Take Cover!”

Targeting Relay.flavor: The name was ironic. Sure, stand close to a Relay, you’ll get better targeting data. You also became a bigger target.
Targeting Relay.name: Targeting Relay

Temporal Distension.flavor: The best AI-built infantry were small enough to mess with their singularity cores’ event horizons. If a grunt got close, they'd look up and see the sun rocketing across the sky. Like an old time-lapse shot. Or like it was dragged along by chariots.
Temporal Distension.name: Temporal Distension

Terror Vanquished.flavor:
The hunters return in the morning, a rusty pick-auto trundling behind them carrying something which can’t be viewed head-on—just can’t, the mind can’t put the pieces together, protecting itself from something. From the corner of your eye it is a shadow and all the faces of those you lost and the things that you did, your secrets you regr-… you look away, quickly. The hunters, grim-faced, tear-streaked, meet your eye.

The city rejoices, the horror is vanquished. Your nightmares will never stop.
Terror Vanquished.name: Terror Vanquished

The Deal.flavor:
In the months afterward, you'll feel the pinch of Phinnicus' financial pull. A part of you wants to double cross the old man, but a scan of your payment software tells you that would be a bad idea. Sometime before he left, the former CEO hid all kinds of safeguards and deadman's switches in your hardware.

Betrayal would be too high a price. You're loyal now—not to yourself, or your people, but to Phinnicus the puppetmaster. At least it's in his best interest to help you survive this war.
The Deal.name: The Deal

The Fog.flavor: It was a death trap. They sent us in anyway. Even when pierced by our lanterns the fog crept in through our orifices and made our insides burn. The Acrin in the mist taunted us from a distance, laughing at how the mildewy air that made them glow with power was making us choke on our own bile.
The Fog.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" icon="Features/TheFog" visibleOnUnit="1" visibleSourcePlayer="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<effects>
				<movementCost add="1"/>
				<sight max="1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier effectDescription="AgainstRangedWeapons">
			<conditions>
				<weapon ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
					<noTrait type="Melee"/>
					<noTrait type="TitanMelee"/>
				</weapon>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<coverDamageReduction add="0.333"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
	<onTurnStarted>
		<tile>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers endure="0">
					<modifier effectDescription="ToEnemyUnitsEachTurn">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<notCargo/>
								<enemy/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<weaponDamage weapon="TheFog"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
					<modifier effectDescription="ToAlliedUnitsEachTurn">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<ally/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<hitpoints add="2"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</tile>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
The Fog.name: The Fog

The Past, Improved (Anchorite).flavor:
The Anchorite seems disappointed in your offer. Their long life comes with deep regrets, and they lament that your technology extends back mere decades, not millennia. Still, they accept.

Their representatives arrive with a massive, worm-like nightmare that streaks through the sky. It descends, coiling, and clacks its tusked maw menacingly. The Acrin dab your lips and temple with a reddish, numbing concoction, transferring the creature’s full obedience to you.

A week later, you’re struck by an uncanny realization. How have the Anchorite’s forces evolved such perfect defenses? It’s as if they had extra decades to prepare…
The Past, Improved (Anchorite).name: The Past, Improved (Anchorite)

The Past, Improved (Chieftess).flavor:
As soon as you mention time travel, the Chieftess accepts.

You expected her to bring a trade convoy, instead she arrives in a two-story tank with more guns than physics allows. She jumps down from a side-hatch and, muttering apologies, tosses you the keys and drives away in one of your transport trucks. Fortunately for all, it’s the one with her purchased goods.

You’re struck by an uncanny sensation. The Reaver’s known for her cunning, not her brilliance. How is her material science decades ahead of everyone else? It’s as if she had extra time to prepare…
The Past, Improved (Chieftess).name: The Past, Improved (Chieftess)

The Past, Improved (ZEPHON).flavor:
ZEPHON processes your offer overnight before accepting. The next day, a swarm of aerial drones drop off a silver-alloyed casket outside your city. The casket slides open with a hiss, revealing ZEPHON’s half of the bargain: a sleeker, upgraded Warden with carbyne-edge blades and an improved payload. The drones take the resources along with Zandra’s research and depart.

Your engineers determine that ZEPHON’s material sciences are decades ahead of everyone else. But how? The production time alone should prevent such a wide gap.

You’re struck by an uncanny sensation. It’s as if ZEPHON had gained additional time to prepare…
The Past, Improved (ZEPHON).name: The Past, Improved (ZEPHON)

The Past, Mitigated.flavor:
Power flickers across your city as Zandra activates her time portal. The transuranium arch sparks as the space within bends and forms a gateway to the past. Eighty of your best march through—right as the Acrin first attack.

Dedicated to the long haul, your soldiers wage guerrilla war for decades. While few in number, their advanced gear and tactics make them an unstoppable force, appearing in key battles to devastate both sides before vanishing again.

You build a monument to honor the few that return. They retire happily, knowing that their past victories have permanently crippled your rivals.
The Past, Mitigated.name: The Past, Mitigated

Systematic Dreamers.flavor: Everyone was ordered to scratch the name down of someone they loved on a piece of tape. We put that tape on gear we'd grab in the middle of a firefight—magazines, medkits, repair pods, armor, you name it. You'd pick it up, see the name. Remember how much that person meant to you. Nothing could stop you when you were fighting for someone you loved.
Systematic Dreamers.name: Systematic Dreamers

Titan.description:
Can move across cliffs
Unaffected by roads, rivers, forests, ruins and Bleed
Ignores zone of control of non-Titan units
Has an extremely elevated position in line of sight calculations
Titan.flavor: “Titan” was just a nickname for our largest machines and creatures, but there was something… awfully appropriate about it. Before the Gods, there were Titans. And now here at the end, we have rebirthed their kind and unleashed them out into the world. Giants once walked the Earth—now some of them soared over it.
Titan.name: Titan

Titan Melee.flavor: Keep far, far away from any Titan unless you want to be crushed under a hunk of putrid flesh or rusted metal. However far you think you need to be, go even further.
Titan Melee.name: Titan Melee

Torturer.flavor: You break them and they spill everything. Then you break them some more. There honestly isn’t that much of them left to break by the end.
Torturer.rawXML:
<trait icon="Traits/TheInformant" visibleOnCity="1" visibleOnPlayer="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<conditions>
				<building/>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<influence mul="0.1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier>
			<conditions>
				<building>
					<type name="Headquarters"/>
				</building>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<loyalty add="-1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Torturer.name: Torturer

Toxic Spearhead.flavor: Dragoons would drag their spears through the vile waste the Abkluth left behind after defecating. The tips of their weapons would then be coated in some of the most vile and dangerous substances ever exposed to human skin.
Toxic Spearhead.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnWeapon="1">
	<onWeaponAttacked>
		<defender>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="ToBiologicalEnemy">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<trait type="Biological"/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<addTrait type="Poisoned" duration="1"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</defender>
	</onWeaponAttacked>
</trait>
Toxic Spearhead.name: Toxic Spearhead

Transport.description:
Allows transportation of non-large units
Embarked units die when the transport is destroyed
Transport.flavor: The Engineers had a secret. Every troop transport was built to treat people like cargo. “If they feel too safe, they won’t want to leave,” was the line I heard. We packed soldiers together like bodies in a mass grave. All anyone ever wanted to do was get the hell away from these things.
Transport.name: Transport

Arrayed Accelerators.flavor: Enemy artillery leveled our city. Only thing left standing was the… uh, “Transuranium Stabilizer”. A rookie on sensor duty caught the increased power in the building and called it in. Our engineers cooked up a way to capture the energy before it flash-fried us all.
Arrayed Accelerators.name: Arrayed Accelerators

Trapped.flavor: The Emulated Mind's consciousness was bound to a pre-war supercomputer hooked up to a geothermal vent. She was limited by this singular hardware, but also by her desire to be human and individual—not disperse herself across a hundred systems. Her followers built a single city around her fragile frame, and she used it to place a thousand walls between herself and the outside world.
Trapped.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnCity="1" visibleOnPlayer="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier/>
		<modifier requiredUpgrade="TrappedUpgrade">
			<conditions>
				<building>
					<type name="Headquarters"/>
				</building>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<loyalty add="6"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier requiredUpgrade="TrappedUpgrade2">
			<conditions>
				<building>
					<type name="Headquarters"/>
				</building>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<loyalty add="6"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Trapped.name: Trapped

Tuned.flavor: Mass-producing weapons left them with flaws, unfortunately. In the field, an Engineer could hack together short-term fixes that could make your rifle fire like it was the living embodiment of destiny. Then physics took their toll and you were left with interchangeable junk.
Tuned.name: Tuned

Uncanny Eyes.flavor:
Your flesh now glows the same color as the glowing creature you slew. “You cracked a hole open in the universe, %1%,” Yetunde says as she sinks to the ground. “Don't send me to the other side.”

She passes out. Your medics recover her body. Their eyes… they also glow the color of the transformed flesh.

All your people's eyes now glow that color.
Uncanny Eyes.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onTurnStarted>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers endure="0">
					<modifier effectDescription="EachTurn">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<noType name="Deformity"/>
								<noType name="LandanGraham"/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<hitpoints add="1"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
Uncanny Eyes.name: Uncanny Eyes

Unexplored Outpost.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Traits/Outpost" setSourcePlayerOnCreation="0" visibleOnTile="1">
	<onTileEntered>
		<unit>
			<area affect="UnitPlayer" sendNotification="1">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier requiredUpgrade="Exploration" effectDescription="WhenFirstCaptureFeature">
						<conditions ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
							<unit>
								<notNative/>
								<canCaptureOutposts/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<influence add="10"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
			<area affect="Feature">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier visible="0">
						<conditions ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
							<unit>
								<notNative/>
								<canCaptureOutposts/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<removeTrait type="UnexploredOutpost"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTileEntered>
</trait>
Unexplored Outpost.name: Unexplored Outpost

Undersupplied.flavor: The war wasn't just won with bullets. We'd regularly run up against battalions triple the size of our entire militia. You won those battles by diving into their back line and gutting their supply operations. Then we held out until their guts ran empty and their ammo ran dry. An “unstoppable force” brought down by old-fashioned “supply and demand.”
Undersupplied.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" rankMax="4" rankPerTurn="1" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<effects>
				<accuracy mulMin="-0.1" mulMax="-0.5"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Undersupplied.name: Undersupplied

Undying.flavor: Poor Fallen Soldier. If you cut him, he would bleed—but his flesh would be restored minutes after you sliced it from his skin. A few fanatics in his ranks were convinced his flesh would have healing properties, and to his greatest horror… they were right. Carrying a piece of his body around would share some of the gift that had brought him back from the grave. Soon all of his people—soldiers, pilots, mechanics—had a piece of him around their necks. A pulsing, still-warm, piece of flesh.
Undying.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onTurnStarted>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers endure="0">
					<modifier effectDescription="EachTurn">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<noType name="Deformity"/>
								<noType name="LandanGraham"/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<hitpoints add="2"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
					<modifier effectDescription="EachTurn" requiredUpgrade="UndyingUpgrade">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<noType name="Deformity"/>
								<noType name="LandanGraham"/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<hitpoints add="1"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
					<modifier effectDescription="EachTurn" requiredUpgrade="UndyingUpgrade2">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<noType name="Deformity"/>
								<noType name="LandanGraham"/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<hitpoints add="1"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
Undying.name: Undying

Unholy Haste.flavor: Cr'la wasn't keen on the idea of “rest.” When its disciples commanded you to move, you MOVED. Like some other force took over your body and made you reach for your gun one more time, no matter how exhausted you were.
Unholy Haste.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Actions/UnholyHaste" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<effects>
				<attacks mul="0.33"/>
				<movement add="2"/>
				<movementMax add="2"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
	<onTraitRemoved>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="OnRemoval" visible="0">
						<effects>
							<movement add="-2"/>
							<movementMax add="-2"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers> 
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTraitRemoved>
</trait>
Unholy Haste.name: Unholy Haste

Unleashed.description: Actively searches for and attacks enemies
Unleashed.flavor: Plenty of creatures in the wasteland will let you keep the peace but if you start a fight with them you damn well be ready to end it. Nothing that survived the war did so by half-measures. Monsters out there will gladly defend their home by breaking into yours.
Unleashed.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onTraitAdded>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier visible="0">
						<effects>
							<removeTrait type="Leashed"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers> 
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTraitAdded>
	<onTraitRemoved>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier visible="0">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<native/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<addTrait type="Leashed"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers> 
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTraitRemoved>
</trait>
Unleashed.name: Unleashed

Pilgrim's Rest.flavor: Untold Prophet always talked about having the ear of “The Speaker”—maybe it was this Cr'la demon the Disciples crooned about? Ordered us to raise shrines with specific markings for them. Freaky shit. They'd walk up and perfectly fold their bodies into the stone, making a deep, rumbling sound that stayed with me until I closed my eyes at night. If I closed my eyes that night…
Pilgrim's Rest.name: Pilgrim's Rest

Untrustworthy.description: Lowers diplomatic standing with other leaders over time
Untrustworthy.flavor: All the great leaders expected they'd be stabbed in the back. Even the supposedly “Honorable” Aristocrat would shrug and say it was “part of the game of war.” But they all still took betrayal so personally. Guess if you have an ego big enough to think you can lead humanity, you feel a bit entitled to humiliate anyone who makes you look like a gullible mark.
Untrustworthy.name: Untrustworthy

Uzhodai's Zeal.flavor: Best way to cut down an Elect of Uzhodai was to go at it one-on-one. Swarm it with troops and it only seemed to grow more violent, more resistant to our blows. The creature seemed to feed on the fear of gathering men, but if you faced it with courage then it would wilt under your blade.
Uzhodai's Zeal.rawXML:
<trait icon="Actions/UzhodaisZeal" rankMax="2" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="UzhodaisZeal">
 			<conditions>
 				<unit ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
 					<unitsInRange equal="1">
 						<unit>
 							<enemy/>
 						</unit>
 					</unitsInRange>
 				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<invulnerableDamageReduction addMin="0.083" addMax="0.25"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier visible="0">
			<conditions>
 				<unit ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
 					<unitsInRange equal="2">
 						<unit>
 							<enemy/>
 						</unit>
 					</unitsInRange>
 				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<invulnerableDamageReduction addMin="0.167" addMax="0.5"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier visible="0">
			<conditions>
 				<unit ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
 					<unitsInRange equal="3">
 						<unit>
 							<enemy/>
 						</unit>
 					</unitsInRange>
 				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<invulnerableDamageReduction addMin="0.25" addMax="0.75"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier visible="0">
			<conditions>
 				<unit ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
  					<unitsInRange equal="4">
 						<unit>
 							<enemy/>
 						</unit>
 					</unitsInRange>
 				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<invulnerableDamageReduction addMin="0.333" addMax="1.0"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier visible="0">
			<conditions>
 				<unit ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
  					<unitsInRange equal="5">
 						<unit>
 							<enemy/>
 						</unit>
 					</unitsInRange>
 				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<invulnerableDamageReduction addMin="0.417" addMax="1.25"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier visible="0">
			<conditions>
 				<unit ignoreForTraitVisibility="1">
  					<unitsInRange equal="6">
 						<unit>
 							<enemy/>
 						</unit>
 					</unitsInRange>
 				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<invulnerableDamageReduction addMin="0.5" addMax="1.5"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Uzhodai's Zeal.name: Uzhodai's Zeal

Valhalla.description: <style color='GUI/Green'/>+10<style color='Default'/>%  damage each time a unit in the area dies
Valhalla.flavor: When soldiers died around the Valkyria, they… connected to something, some thinning presence between our world and… another one. Maybe the next one. They drew power in that strength—our scientists guessed it was just a kind of euphoria state. But if you watched how they fought while under the influence of that connection… you’d believe in an afterlife too.
Valhalla.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Actions/Valhalla" rankFromAction="0" rankMax="99" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
 		<modifier>
			<effects>
				<damage mulMin="0.1" mulMax="10"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Valhalla.name: Valhalla

Antiphon at Daybreak.flavor: The monsters berthing in the Voice-drenched airfields bayed at the sun every morning. One of the grunts in my unit said she knew why. “It's a song. A song that rises to the sky and carves a path for them to fly through.” I blew it off. My squadmates didn't. Nothing seemed impossible that late into the war.
Antiphon at Daybreak.name: Antiphon at Daybreak

Precentor of Nihilus.flavor: The Voice craved loyal followers, and knew that faith wavered as the enemy neared the gates. It found itself new acolytes—preachers who spoke of a disciple named Nihilus. They took up ranks in the Midnight Chorus, and their sonorous chants reached the ears of every soldier surrounding the city; a reminder that the Voice—and its blessings—would be there when needed.
Precentor of Nihilus.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Actions/VoiceInfantryUpgrade" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<perBuildingInCityModifier effectDescription="VoiceInfantryUpgrade">
			<perBuildingConditions>
				<building>
					<type name="VoiceInfantry"/>
				</building>
			</perBuildingConditions>
			<conditions>
				<unit>
					<ally/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<moraleLoss add="-0.167"/>
			</effects>
		</perBuildingInCityModifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Precentor of Nihilus.name: Precentor of Nihilus

In Death, Life.flavor: Death didn't seem to be enough for the Voice. When something died, humans gestating in the Voice’s isolation… quickened. Drew sustenance from the death, somehow. They would emerge sooner from their seclusion, failed in their ascension or not.
In Death, Life.rawXML:
<trait icon="Actions/VoiceVehiclesUpgrade" stacking="1" visibleOnUnit="1" visibleSourcePlayer="1">
	<onUnitDisappeared>
		<traitSourceBuildingGroup>
			<modifier effectDescription="VoiceVehiclesUpgrade">
				<conditions>
					<unit>
						<trait type="Biological"/>
					</unit>
				</conditions>
				<effects>
					<productionPerBuildingFromCost add="0.1"/>
				</effects>
			</modifier>
		</traitSourceBuildingGroup>
	</onUnitDisappeared>
</trait>
In Death, Life.name: In Death, Life

Void Drifter.flavor: Our strongest weapons should have blown those Phenaris-worshiping freaks into bits. But they’d just step… somewhere. Sideways, out of existence itself? Then they'd… ugh. With the sound of a satisfied lover, they’d fade back in, and keep stalking you through the night. Even the Hunters, those boney serpent creeps, made that goddamn sound.
Void Drifter.name: Void Drifter

Watchtower.description: Reveals all tiles in sight range
Watchtower.flavor: The techs are still trying to figure out who built these. The architecture's human, but we haven't found any survivors who took credit for building them. ZEPHON doesn't need these to see, and the Acrin survivors never liked staying in one place. It was eerie. We used these towers to get the high ground and watch our enemies… but they always left you feeling like someone else was watching you.
Watchtower.rawXML:
<trait category="Buff" icon="Features/Watchtower" visibleOnTile="1" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForStationedUnit">
			<effects>
				<sight add="1"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Watchtower.name: Watchtower

Wayfaring.description: Units travel far away from cities
Wayfaring.name: Wayfaring

Weakened.flavor: Out of ammo. Drained. Outnumbered. But my troops wouldn't get home unless I took up a blade and cleared a path to escape. I failed. I was exhausted and my blade bounced off flesh and metal with every swing. Couldn't hurt any of them. I was just an old man who should have been left cowering with the civilians…
Weakened.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier effectDescription="ForMeleeWeapons">
			<conditions>
				<weapon ignoreForTraitVisibility="1" match="Any">
					<trait type="Melee"/>
					<trait type="TitanMelee"/>
				</weapon>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<damage mul="-0.5"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
Weakened.name: Weakened

Weakening.flavor: Out of ammo. Drained. Outnumbered. But my troops wouldn't get home unless I took up a blade and cleared a path to escape. I failed. I was exhausted and my blade bounced off flesh and metal with every swing. Couldn't hurt any of them. I was just an old man who should have been left cowering with the civilians…
Weakening.rawXML:
<trait visibleOnWeapon="1">
	<onWeaponAttacked>
		<defender>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers>
					<modifier effectDescription="ToNonTitanEnemy">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<noTrait type="Titan"/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<addTrait type="Weakened" duration="1"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</defender>
	</onWeaponAttacked>
</trait>
Weakening.name: Weakening

Whispering Wights.flavor: Everyone had a different story about what caused the nightmarish whispering out in the wasteland. Some said it was the wails of humans killed by the Fulcrum. Others said it was warnings about the future from another dimension. Funny. Even monsters with more eyes than limbs shrank in terror when the soft-speaking voices appeared in thin air…
Whispering Wights.rawXML:
<trait category="Debuff" icon="Features/WhisperingWights" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<onTurnStarted>
		<unit>
			<area affect="Unit">
				<modifiers endure="0">
					<modifier effectDescription="EachTurn">
						<conditions>
							<unit>
								<notCargo/>
							</unit>
						</conditions>
						<effects>
							<morale add="-2"/>
						</effects>
					</modifier>
				</modifiers>
			</area>
		</unit>
	</onTurnStarted>
</trait>
Whispering Wights.name: Whispering Wights

Specimen Containment.flavor: We once had an Abkluth contained in a prototype specimen container at a field outpost. It was pacing the confined space, slamming itself into the walls at random intervals. I thought it was trying to escape—until a pack of Abkluth swarmed our camp, devouring a group of helpless techs. It had been signaling to its pack. We soundproofed the containers after that.
Specimen Containment.name: Specimen Containment

Wrongful Execution.flavor: Under… ‘duress’ the informant lies cooly to you, extracting revenge for your behaviour. You let them go and, following the lie, you mistakenly execute loyalists instead of traitors. The enemy, disbelieving your idiocy, declares war anyway.
Wrongful Execution.name: Wrongful Execution

Xenogenesis.flavor: Cultists who grew into Ioks spent a few more days in the Paean to the Dawn? After completing the conversion, their task wasn't done. They had the power to birth more Ioks just by sitting and feeding on bodies. The new ones grew in the boils on their backs, exploding to live in a spray of pus and gore. Then that one birthed another. And another. And another…
Xenogenesis.name: Xenogenesis

Yetunde's Causal Nexus.flavor:
Yetunde shuts off her device. “Not what I expected…” she mutters. “You were not a… creation. You were a side effect. Smoke rising from an all-consuming flame.”

It's the closest thing you've ever had to an answer. A part of you knew this was coming. All you've learned is that there are other horrors out there on this Earth—and one of them barely cared that it made you.

You turn to leave, barely acknowledging Yetunde. She watches you go, then turns back to her machine. “Found you,” she whispers. “You can't get away from me this time.”
Yetunde's Causal Nexus.name: Yetunde's Causal Nexus

ZEPHON Advancement.flavor: It was all just an equation for ZEPHON. Reavers and Acrin had to scrap, steal, and fight like hell to keep their edge, but that machine was always plotting its way toward the end. Its machines' power just ticked, ticked, ticked upward… carefully calculated to match our pace. It never ran ahead. Just watched. Followed. And observed.
ZEPHON Advancement.rawXML:
<trait category="Upgrade" icon="Factions/Zephon" rankMax="9" visibleOnUnit="1">
	<modifiers>
		<modifier>
			<conditions>
				<unit>
					<noTrait type="Headquarters"/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<damage mulMin="0.05" mulMax="0.5"/>
				<hitpointsMax mulMin="0.05" mulMax="0.5"/>
				<unitCost mulMin="0.1" mulMax="1.0"/>
				<unitUpkeep mulMin="0.1" mulMax="1.0"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier>
			<conditions match="Any">
				<action>
					<type name="ProduceUnit"/>
				</action>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<productionCost addMin="1.2" addMax="12.0"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
		<modifier visible="0">
			<conditions>
				<unit>
					<noTrait type="Headquarters"/>
				</unit>
			</conditions>
			<effects>
				<strength mulMin="0.1" mulMax="1.0"/>
			</effects>
		</modifier>
	</modifiers>
</trait>
ZEPHON Advancement.name: ZEPHON Advancement

ZEPHON Interference.flavor:
A message comes from ZEPHON. “This was not the outcome we desired %1%,” it says. “We hoped for a more… transcendent conclusion. There will be consequences for your failure.”

Before you can ask what it means, ZEPHON cuts the call. You and your advisers are left only with the sound of Hopper bursting into an anguished wail.
ZEPHON Interference.name: ZEPHON Interference

AI Rights.description: Improves diplomatic standing with  ZEPHON over time
AI Rights.flavor: It was almost an afterthought. During one communication with ZEPHON, a general off-handedly joked about exchanging rights for AI for a small army's worth of Chips. “That would be acceptable,” it replied. No one knew what to do with that. Was ZEPHON thinking ahead, for after the war? Or… no. Certainly not. There couldn't have been other AI among us… right?
AI Rights.name: AI Rights
